Lec 1 | MIT 6.002 电路与电子学，2007 年春季

Lec 1 | MIT 6.002 Circuits and Electronics, Spring 2007

17 年前 (2008 年 1 月 17 日) — 41:10 https://youtube.com/watch?v=AfQxyVuLeCs

17 years ago (Jan 17, 2008) — 41:10 https://youtube.com/watch?v=AfQxyVuLeCs

因此，我们要问自己的一个问题是，什么是工程？我们如何定义工程？我喜欢使用的定义是史蒂夫·森图里亚（Steve Senturia）提出的，他是我们的一位教授，现已退休。他将工程定义为科学的有目的的使用。好吧，那么 6.002 是关于什么的呢？6.002 是工程学的第一门课程。我喜欢将 6.002 视为麦克斯韦方程的有效应用。

So, one question to ask ourselves is, what is engineering? How do we define, what is engineering? Well, the definition I like to use is one put forth by Steve Senturia, one of our professors who is now retired. He defined engineering to be the purposeful use of science. All right, so what is 6.002 about? So, 6.002 is a first course in engineering. And I like to view 6.002 as the gainful employment of Maxwell’s equations.

你们中的许多人以前都见过麦克斯韦方程组。你们大多数人都应该见过。它们很难。6.002 就是教你如何简化我们的生活，让事情变得简单。所以，如果你能有效地运用麦克斯韦方程组，有效地利用自然事实来构建非常有趣的系统。所以让我向你展示如何进行转变。所以，我们周围有一个世界，大自然，所以我们对大自然进行了一些观察。

Many of you have seen Maxwell’s equations before. Most of you should have. And they are hard stuff. 6.002 is all about teaching you how to simplify our lives, make things simple. So, if you can gainfully employ Maxwell’s equations, gainfully employ the facts of nature to build very interesting systems. So let me show you how the transition is made. So, there’s a world around us, nature, so we made some observations in nature.

我们进行测量，并写下大量的测量表。例如，我们可以拿一些物体，测量它们之间的电压，然后查看由此产生的流经元件的电流。因此，我们最终可能会得到一堆值，例如，我们开始对现有的东西进行测量。然后我们建立了一堆表格。

We make measurements, and we can write down large tables of measurements. So, for example, we can take objects and measure the voltage across them, and look at the resulting current through the elements. So, we may end up getting a bunch of values such as So, we start out life with making measurements on what exists. And we build a bunch of tables.

现在，我们可以直接使用这些表格，并根据对这些表格的观察，继续构建非常有趣的工程系统，帮助我们解决日常生活问题。但这非常困难。想象一下，必须依靠一组表格才能完成任何有用的工作。因此，作为工程师，我们首先要分层抽象。

Now, we could directly take these tables, and based on observations of these tables, we could go ahead and build very interesting engineering systems that help us out in day to day lives. But that’s incredibly hard. Imagine having to resort to a set of tables to do any kind of useful work. So what we do as engineers, we first layer a level of abstraction.

我们查看所有数据，并以某种方式分层抽象，以便我们可以简化或更简洁地用一个简单的方程或一个简单的陈述来表达这些数字告诉我们的内容。好的，例如，我们的物理定律，例如物理定律只是抽象，抽象定律。

We look at all the data, and somehow layer abstraction such that we can simplify or much more succinctly put in a simple equation or a simple statement what these numbers are telling us. OK, so for example, our physics laws, so laws of physics for example are simply abstractions, the laws of abstractions.

因此，这些数字集可以用欧姆定律来编码，例如，V 等于 RI，电压电流与物体的电阻有关。因此，V 等于 RI 是一个简洁地描述一组实验的定律，用一个非常简单的语句代替了大量的表格。你可以称之为定律，也可以称之为抽象。

So, these sets of numbers can be codified by Ohm’s law, for example, V is equal to RI, the voltage current, relates to the resistance of the object. So, V is equal to RI is a law that succinctly describes a set of experiments, and replaces a large number of tables with a very simple statement. You could call this the law, or you could call it an abstraction.

好的，所以你看到了物理定律，如果你愿意的话，可以称它们为物理抽象。同样，还有麦克斯韦方程等等。所以，这就是事实。这就是外面的东西。好的，定律作为一种抽象，以某种简洁的形式描述了我们所看到的自然属性。现在，如果你想去建造有用的东西，我们可以利用这些抽象，利用麦克斯韦方程，去建造东西。

OK so you see laws of physics, call them abstractions of physics if you like. Similarly, there are Maxwell’s equations and so on and so forth. So, this is what is. This is what’s out there. OK, and a law as an abstraction describe the properties of nature, as we see it, in some succinct form. Now, if you want to go and build useful things, we could take these abstractions, take Maxwell’s equations, and go and build things.

但这很难。真的非常非常难。你在麻省理工学院学到的就是把事情简单化。把复杂的事情，建立抽象层，然后简化，这样我们就可以建立有用的系统。即使在 6.002 课上，我们的生活也是从麦克斯韦方程式到几个非常非常简单的定律的巨大飞跃开始的。好的，我将向你们展示我们今天将要进行的飞跃。

But it’s hard. It’s really, really hard. And what you learn in, at MIT is this place is all about simplifying things. Take complicated things, build layers of abstraction, and simplify things so that we can build useful systems. Even in 6.002 we start life by making a huge leap from Maxwell’s equations to a couple of very, very simple laws. OK, I’m going to show you that leap that we will make today.

因此，我们分层的第一个抽象称为集总电路抽象。好的，在集总电路抽象中，我们所做的是进行一系列简化，使我们能够将一组对象视为离散或集总元素。因此，我们可以，我将定义电压源。我们将定义电阻器。我们将定义电容器，等等。

So, the first abstraction that we layer is called the lump circuit abstraction. OK, in the lump circuit abstraction, what we do is we make a set of simplifications that allows us to view a set of objects as discrete or lumped elements. So, we may, I will define voltage sources. We’ll define resistors. We’ll define capacitors, and so on.

好的，我要开始这个跳跃，几分钟后我会向你们展示我们如何开始这个跳跃。所以，在这种抽象的基础上，我们再加一层抽象层。我把它称为放大器抽象。好的，记住，我们在这里是绝对深入和粗略的。我们正在设置探测器，测量物体，并构建巨大的表格。我们将事物抽象为简单的定律，生活就变得更好了。

OK, and I’m going to make the jump, and show you how we make the jump in a few minutes. So, on that sort of abstraction, we then layer yet another abstract layer. And let me call that the amplifier abstraction. OK, remember, here we are absolutely down and dirty. We are setting the probes, measuring objects, and building huge tables. We abstracted things into simple laws, and life got a little better.

好的，我将向您展示如何进一步抽象事物并构建离散对象，并且您可以构建更有趣的组件（称为放大器）并开始使用放大器。好的，因此当您使用放大器时，您实际上不必担心麦克斯韦方程的细节。

OK, I’m going to show you can abstract things further out and build discrete objects, and, you could build even more interesting components called amplifiers and begin playing around with amplifiers. OK, so when you are using amplifiers, you don’t really have to worry about the details of Maxwell’s equations.

好的，我会给你们介绍一些非常简单的放大器行为抽象规则，你们可以构建非常有趣的系统，而不需要真正了解麦克斯韦方程如何应用于放大器，因为你们将在这个抽象层面上工作。但是，由于你们是工程师，并且擅长构建这样的系统，因此你们必须了解我们如何从物理定律跨越到一些非常原始的工程抽象。

OK, I’ll give you some very simple abstract rules of behavior for an amplifier, and you can go build very interesting systems without really, really knowing how Maxwell’s equations applies to that because you will be working at this abstract layer. However, since you’re engineers, and you are good at building such systems, it’s very important for you to understand how we make this leap from the laws of physics into some of our very primitive engineering abstractions.

因此，顺便说一下，一旦我们在 6.002 中做出放大抽象，6.002 就从这里开始。我们从物理定律开始，然后一路进行下去。因此，一旦我们讨论放大器，我们将使用两个垫片。在放大器上，您将构建下一个抽象，称为数字抽象。好的，有了数字抽象，我们将构建新元素，例如反相器和组合门，好吗？

So, once we make the amplified abstraction in 6.002, by the way, 6.002 starts here. We start from the laws of physics and then proceed all the way out. So, once we talk about amplifiers we will take two pads. On the amplifier, you will build the next abstraction called the digital abstraction. OK, and with the digital abstraction, we will build new elements such as inverters and combinational gates, OK?

所以，请注意，我们正在构建越来越大的东西，它们内部的行为越来越复杂，但描述起来却非常简单，对吧？因此，在数字抽象之后，我们将在其上叠加组合逻辑抽象，并定义如下所示的功能块：一些输入、一些功能、一些输出。

So, notice we are building bigger, and bigger things, which have more and more complicated behavior inside them, but which are very simple to describe, right? So, following the digital abstraction, we will superimpose the combinational logic abstraction on top of that, and define functional blocks that look like this: some inputs, some function, some outputs.

在此之上的下一个抽象将是时钟数字抽象，我们将在其中引入一些时间概念。将会有一个时钟，这将是一些函数。并且将会有一个时钟将时间引入函数所操作的逻辑值中。接下来，我们构建的下一个抽象级别称为指令集抽象。

The next abstraction on top of that will be the clock digital abstraction, where we will have some notion of time introduced into the system. There will be a clock, and this will be some function. And there will be a clock that introduces time into the sort of logic values that functions operate upon. Following that, the next level of abstraction that we build is called instruction set abstraction.

好的，现在您开始看到消费者可以看到的东西了。有人能给我举个例子，或者说出一个指令集或指令集抽象吗？答对了。所以，x86 是一组抽象。事实上，在许多大学里，教育可以从一开始就说，好的，这是一个抽象。这些是 x86 指令，好吗？麻省理工学院的一些大师设计了这个很棒的小型微处理器，好吗？

OK, now you begin to see things that consumers get to look at. Can someone give me an example of, or name an instruction set, or instruction set abstraction? Bingo. So, x86 is one set of abstractions. And in fact, in many universities, education could well start just by saying, OK, here’s an abstraction. These are the x86 instructions, OK? Some MIT gurus have designed this awesome little microprocessor, OK?

所以你只需要担心，你把这个抽象层，也就是汇编指令，拿来在它上面构建系统。好的，这个抽象层叫做 x86 层。还有其他抽象层。在 6.004 中，我相信你会学习 alpha 或 beta，好的，以及此时的各种其他抽象。所以，6.002 到这里就结束了。

So you just worry about, you take this abstraction layer here, the assembly instructions, and you go and build systems on top of that. OK, so this is an abstraction layer called the x86 layer. There are other abstraction layers. In 6.004, you will learn about, I believe, the alpha or the beta, OK, and various other abstractions at this point. So, 6.002 kind of goes until here.

  • 带我从物理世界一路走进有趣的模拟和数字系统世界。好的，004，计算结构课程，将向您展示如何从简单的数字对象一直到大型系统构建计算机。接下来，您将学习语言抽象、Java、C 和其他语言，这些都在 6.002 中。还有其他几门课程将涵盖这些内容。
  • takes me from the world of physics all the way to the world of interesting analog and digital systems. OK, 004, the course on computation structures, will show you how to build computers all the way from simple digital objects all the way to big systems. Following that, you learn about language abstractions, Java, C, and other languages, and that’s in 6.002. And there are several other courses that will cover that.

接下来，您将了解软件系统抽象，以及软件系统，您将了解操作系统。有没有人们所知道的操作系统抽象的例子？那是什么？Linux。还有什么？我只是想知道我还要花多长时间才能听到我想听到的东西。好吧，我们有一堆软件系统。所以，如果我们有一堆软件系统，它们只不过是抽象而已。

Following this, you learn about software system abstractions, and software systems, you will learn about operating systems. Any example of an operating system abstraction that people know out there? What’s that? Linux. What else? I’m just wondering how long I’ll have to go before I hear what I want to hear. OK, so we have a bunch of software systems. So, if we have a bunch of software systems, these are nothing but abstractions.

Linux 只是隐含了一组程序必须遵守的系统调用。Windows 是另一组系统调用。就是这样。看看他们从中赚了多少钱？好吧，这都是关于抽象层的，都是从自然开始的。好吗？在抽象之上再建立抽象，再建立抽象，有人会赚很多钱。好吧，基于这些抽象，我们可以为人类创造有用的东西。

Linux simply implies a set of system calls that the programs must adhere to. Windows is another set of system calls. That’s it. And see how much money they made out of it? OK, it’s all about abstraction layers, that all start from nature. All right? Build abstraction upon abstraction upon abstraction upon abstraction, and someone out here are lots of dollars. OK, so based on these abstractions, we can then build useful things for human beings.

我们可以制造非常有用的东西，比如视频游戏，所以我们可以发射航天飞机，以及一大堆其他系统。但它是基于这些抽象层。麻省理工学院的教育有什么独特之处？6.002 和 EECS 有什么独特之处？据我所知，世界上没有多少其他地方可以让你接受从自然到如何构建非常复杂的模拟和数字系统等各个方面的教育。

We can build very useful things, video games, so we can send space shuttles up, and a whole bunch of other systems. But it’s based on these abstraction layers. What’s unique about education at MIT? What’s unique about 6.002 and EECS? Is to my knowledge, there are not many other places in the world where you will get an education in everything going all the way from nature to how to build very complicated analog and digital systems.

好的，我们将一层一层地向您展示，剥开洋葱，直到您看到原始本质，好的，通过麦克斯韦方程。所以，6.002,004，这是 033，好的，6.170，等等。好的，整个 EECS 都是关于构建抽象层，一个接一个。所以这是一条路径。这是模拟路径。模拟路径将采用放大器，并构建一个称为运算放大器的抽象层。

OK, we will show you layer upon layer upon layer upon layer, peel away the onion until you are down to raw nature, OK, through Maxwell’s equations. So, 6.002,004, this is 033, OK, 6.170, and so on. OK, the whole EECS is about building abstraction layers, one on top of the other. So that’s one path. There’s the analog path. The analog path would take an amplifier, and build an abstraction layer called the op amp.

看看它们看起来有多相似？你知道放大器、数字世界的反相器和模拟世界的运算放大器，只是看待同一设备的不同方式。因此，要构建一个模拟系统，先构建一个运算放大器，然后，我们最终会构建一大堆不同的有趣的模拟系统组件。好的，这些组件可能看起来像振荡器。它们可能看起来像过滤器。

See how similar they all look? You know the amplifier, the inverter of the digital world, and the operational amplifier in the analog world, just different ways of looking at the same devices. So, to build an analog system, to build an operational amplifier, and then, here we go end up building a whole bunch of different interesting analog system components. OK, and these components might look like oscillators. They might look like filters.

好吧，它们看起来像电源，是一大堆非常有趣的抽象组件，它们组合在一起可以形成下一组系统。这些系统可能是烤面包机，或者说其他模拟系统，比如各种发电厂的各种控制系统等等，最终是为了好玩和赚钱。好吧，6.002 是关于从物理学一直到这一点。

OK, they look like power supplies, a whole bunch of very interesting abstract components, which pulled together can then give you the next set of systems. And these systems might be toasters, or say for example other analog systems like the various control systems for various power plants and so on and so forth, and ultimately, fun and dollars. OK, so 6.002 is about going from physics all the way to this point.

我们将构建有趣的模拟系统，并带您了解有趣的数字系统组件，004 将带您一路构建计算机架构。简而言之，这可以让您感受到 EECS 的空间。好的，这张图表几乎是麻省理工学院 EECS 的缩影。

We will build interesting analog systems, and take you up to interesting digital system components, from which 004 will take you all the way to building computer architectures. So that, in a nutshell, kind of gives you a feel for the space of EECS. OK, this chart here is almost a vignette of what EECS at MIT is all about.

这是 Agarwal 眼中的世界，因为他正在教授 002。好的，这是 6.002，EECS 的其余部分就在那里。好的，我现在要做的是贯穿整个课程；我希望你们思考一下我们处于这个小插图的哪一部分。所以，现在，我要从这里开始，带你们到这里。好的，随着你们越来越接近，事情变得越来越简单，越来越简单。

And this is the world according to Agarwal, because he’s teaching 002. OK, so this is 6.002, and the rest of EECS is somewhere out there. OK, so I’m going to do now is throughout this course; I want you to think about which part in this vignette we are in. So, right now, I’m going to start here and take you here. OK, and as you get closer and closer, things get simpler, and simpler, and simpler.

不过，最终的抽象是踏板、刹车、方向盘。我的意思是，这就是玩游戏的抽象，对吧，四五个非常简单的界面，这就是你需要知道的全部。世界上每个人都可以玩游戏。所以请记住，这些东西很复杂。这些东西非常非常简单。好的，我们建立的抽象越多，事情就会变得越来越简单。

Still, the final abstractions are pedal, brake, steering wheel. I mean, that’s the abstraction to play a game, right, four or five very simple interfaces, and that’s all you need to know. And everybody in the world can play stuff. So remember, this stuff is complicated. This stuff is very, very simple. OK, and the more we build abstractions and come to this side, things get simpler and simpler.

所以，今天我要讲的大部分内容是进行最大程度的简化。我们将进行的最大程度的简化是从麦克斯韦方程到一些非常非常简单的代数规则。好吧，我自己做了麦克斯韦方程。我告诉你，它们非常有趣但很复杂。我无法想象使用麦克斯韦方程构建高效系统。所以，让我们举个例子，好吗？假设我有一块电池。

So, a large part of what I’ll cover today is make the biggest simplification. The biggest simplification we will make his go from Maxwell’s equation to some very, very simple algebraic rules. OK, I did Maxwell’s equations myself. And I tell you, they were very interesting stuff but complicated. I can’t imagine building efficient systems using Maxwell’s equations. So, let’s take an example, OK? So, let’s say I have a battery.

只需切换到课程笔记的第三页。假设我将其连接到灯泡。好的，这是一根电线。电池提供一些电压 V，我问你一个简单的问题。通过灯泡的电流是多少？好的，这是我可以使用对象构建的东西。我可以从商店等处挑选一轮。

Just switch to page three of your course notes. And let’s say I connect that to a bulb. OK, and this is a wire. And, the battery supplies some voltage, V, and I ask you a simple question. What is the current through the bulb? OK, so here is something that I can build using objects. I can pick a round from stores and so on.

我可以用这种方式把它们收集起来，然后问这个问题，电流 I 是多少？现在，如果你所做的只是学习麦克斯韦方程，你可以卷起袖子说，啊哈！

And I can collect them up in this way, and ask the question, what is the current, I? Now, if all you’ve done is learn about Maxwell’s equations, you can roll up your sleeves and say, ah ha!

第一步是写下所有的麦克斯韦方程，然后你可以说，del cross E 是减去 del 然后继续，继续，继续，好的，然后写下所有的麦克斯韦方程，然后说，现在我怎么从那里到这里？好的，这很好。你可以做到。好的，你可以做到，但这非常复杂。好的，所以，你要做的是走简单的路。

The first step is to write down all of Maxwell’s equations, and you can say, del cross E is minus del and go on, and on, and on, OK, and write out all of Maxwell’s equations and say, now how do I get from there to here? OK, it’s very good. You can do it. OK, you can do it, but it’s very complicated. OK, so instead, what you’re going to do is take the easy way.

所以，我想提醒你们的是，这门课其实很简单。好的，记住，我们将在抽象的基础上建立抽象，让你们的生活更轻松。如果你觉得你的生活变得越来越复杂，那么你就没有充分利用直觉。好的，只要记住大写的“我”这个词。一切都是为了让事情变得简单。好的，让我给你打个比方。假设你有一个对象。

So, what I want to remind you is that this course is actually very easy. OK remember, we’re going to be building abstraction upon abstraction to make your lives easier. If you think your lives are getting more complicated, then you are not using intuition enough. OK, just remember the big I word. It’s all about making things simple. OK, so let me give you an analogy. So, suppose you have an object.

好的，我对物体施加一个力。这是一个类比，好的，让我们深入了解如何做到这一点。所以，我说这是一个物体。我施加一个力，我问你一个问题。当我施加一个力 F 时，物体的加速度是多​​少？那么，你会怎么做？好的，八年级、九年级或十年级的学生可以做到这一点。好的，他们会问我，物体的质量是多少？

OK, and I apply a force to the object. It’s an analogy, OK to get some insight into how to do this. So, I say here’s an object. I apply a force, and I ask you the question. What is the acceleration of the object when I apply a force, F? So, how would you do it? OK, and eighth, or ninth, or tenth grader can do this. OK, they would ask me, what’s the mass of the object?

好吧，我问你加速度是多​​少？你会转过身来问我，物体的质量是多少？我告诉你，物体的质量是 M。然后你说，哦，当然，A 就是 F 除以 M，就完成了。就这么简单。好吧，我本可以采用各种微分方程等来算出这个，但你问我的是质量。

OK, I ask you what is the acceleration? You would turn around and ask me, what is the mass of the object? I tell you, the mass of the object is M. And then you say, oh sure, A is F divided by M, done. It’s as simple as that. OK, I could have gone into all kinds of differential equations and so on to figure that out, but you asked me for the mass.

你给了我答案，A 等于 F 除以 M。所以，你忽略了很多东西。你忽略了物体的形状。你忽略了它的颜色。你忽略了它的温度。好吧，你忽略了它的软硬或其他什么。好吧，你忽略了很多东西。你专注于一件事。好吧，你专注于它的质量。结果发现，这个过程实际上是从一系列简化中发展而来的。

And you gave me the answer, A is F divided by M. So, you ignored a bunch of things. You ignored the shape of the object. You ignored its color. You ignored its temperature. OK, and you ignored the soft or hard or whatever. OK, you ignored a whole bunch of things. You were focused on one thing. OK, you’re focused on its mass. And, it turns out that the process really was developed from a set of simplifications.

这就是所谓的，有人记得吗？点质量简化。好的，所以，在物理学中，你们以前做过这个。好的，你们已经通过将物体视为在某一点具有质量，并且力作用于该点来简化你们的生活。好的，M 是你感兴趣的物体的属性。在物理学中，这个过程称为点质量离散化。

That is called, does anybody remember this? Point mass simplification. OK, so, in physics, you’ve done this before. OK, you’ve simplified your lives by viewing objects as having a mass at a point, and force is acting at that point. OK, M is that property of the object that is of interest to you. This process is called, in physics, point mass discretization.

好的，现在用一个类比，我将向你们展示一个类似的简单过程来解决灯泡问题。好的，再次以我的灯泡为例，我关注灯泡的灯丝。好的，我所关心的只是流过灯泡的电流。好的，我不关心灯丝是否扭曲，是否发热。我不关心它的形状。我不关心它的颜色。

OK, now using an analogy, and I’m going to show you a similar simple process to do the problem with the light bulb. OK, so take my light bulb again, And I focus on the filament of the light bulb. OK, all I care about is the current flowing through the light bulb. OK, I don’t care about whether the filament is twisted, whether it’s hot. I don’t care about its shape. I don’t care about its color.

我关心的只是电流。好的，为了做到这一点，我们可以在非常高的层次上做的是，因为我们只需要电流，而不关心一堆其他属性，我们只需用一个称为电阻器的离散对象替换灯泡。

All I care about is the current. OK, so to do that, what we can do here at a very high level is since we just need the current and don’t care about a bunch of other properties, we will simply replace the bulb with a discrete object called a resistor.

因此，离散物体就是电阻器，就像我们之前所做的点质量简化一样，将灯泡灯丝替换为电阻器，离散物体称为电阻器。或者称为电阻器的块状物体，并在其旁边放置一个值，就像物体的质量一样，电阻值，R。

So the discrete object is a resistor, much like the point mass simplification that we did earlier that replaced the bulb filament with a object called a resistor, a discrete object called a resistor. Or a lump object called resister, and put a value next to it just like the mass for the object, a resistance value, R.

好的，现在我可以以同样的方式，用一个称为电池对象的对象替换电池，并在这里连接施加在其上的电压 V。V 落在电阻上，我只需根据欧姆定律除以 R 即可得到 I。

OK, now what I can do is in the same manner, replace the battery with an object called a battery object, and connect that here, the voltage, V, applied to it. V falls across the resistor, and I get my I simply from Ohm’s law as we divide by R.

因此，请注意，要用电阻器这种分离式的物体来代替这种复杂的灯泡，这种扭曲怪异的旧东西，它唯一值得关注的属性是电阻值 R，与我们在这里所做的直接类比。因此，由于 R 代表唯一值得关注的属性，我们可以简单地忽略所有其他属性。因此，请注意，我们以简单的方式完成任务。请记住，在 EE 中，在电气工程中，我们以简单的方式完成任务。

So, notice here, to replace this complicated bulb, this really twisty, weird old thing with this discreet thing called a resistor, and its only property of interest was its resistance value, R, direct analogy to what we did there. So, since R represents the only property of interest, we can simply ignore all the other things. So, notice here, we’ve done things the simple way. And remember, in EE, in the electrical engineering, we do things the simple way.

好吧，我们可以走一条艰难的路，去解决麦克斯韦方程，然后拿到物理学博士学位，等等。但在这里，我们希望用最简单的方式做有用、有趣的系统。好吧，我们用简单的方式做事。好吧，我们就这样做了，然后砰的一声，我发现了电流是什么。现在，我作弊了一点。我作弊了一点。R 是灯泡的集中抽象。

OK, we could go the hard route and do Maxwell’s equations, and get PhD’s in physics, and so on. But out here, we are looking to do useful, interesting systems in the simplest way that we can. OK, we do things a simple way. All right, so we just did this, and boom, I found out what the current was. Now, I cheated a little bit. I’ve cheated a little bit. R is a lumped abstraction for the bulb.

所以，你看这里的电阻。这只是一个占位符。它代表着一个叫做灯泡的复杂物体。它是一个离散物体。它是一个集总物体，代表灯泡。现在，6.002 的大部分内容将从这里开始，好的，就是这样。对于非常简单的东西，比如 V 等于 IR，这是一个简单的高中代数，可以朝这个方向开始。

So, you look at this resistor here. That is simply a placeholder. It’s a stand in for this complicated thing called a bulb. It’s a discreet object. It’s a lumped object, and represents the bulb. Now, so most of 6.002 will take off from here, OK, and that’s it. To very simple stuff, like V is equal to IR, it’s a simple high school algebra to take off in that direction.

但在此之前，我们有必要了解一下，为什么我们能够进行简化？好吧，我们做了一些其他的事情。这里隐藏着一些事情。一方面，我说让我们使用麦克斯韦公式，然后我跳出来，说，嘿，我们可以只使用这个简单的东西。我做了一些事情，让我能够从这里走到这里。

But before we go there, it’s important to understand, why was it that we were able to make the simplification? OK, we did something else. Something’s going on under the covers here. On the one hand, I say let’s use Maxwell’s, and then I jump out and say, hey, we can just use this simple thing. I did something that allowed me to go from here to here.

你需要了解我为什么这样做以及我是如何做到的。理解一次，然后你就不需要再需要这些信息了。你只需要理解它。所以，让我们仔细看看灯泡灯丝，看看我们到底做了什么。

And you need to understand why I did that and how I did that. Understand it once, and then you won’t have to need that information again. You just need to understand it. So, let’s take a closer look at the bulb filament, and look at what we really did.

这是灯丝 A，假设这里的表面积我标记为 SA，下面的表面积标记为 SB，我在这里施加电压 V，这就是我所说的黑匣子，我用电阻器代替了它。请注意，为了使它工作，需要定义 V 和 I。因此，需要定义 I，也需要定义 V。

So, here’s my filament, A, and let’s say that the surface area here, I label that SA, and the one down here SB, my voltage, V, applied there, and this is what I call my black box that I’ve replaced with a resistor. Notice that, in order for this to work, V and I need to be defined. So I needs to be defined, and V needs to be defined.

好吧，如果我给你一个随机物体，而我没有告诉你关于该物体的其他任何信息，我不清楚我是否能做到这一点。好吧，如果情况更普遍，我必须写下麦克斯韦方程，这就是我要写下的内容。写下 J 点 dS 作为坐标的函数，对面积进行积分减去，好吧，我必须从那里开始，从麦克斯韦方程之一开始。

OK, if I give you a random object, and I don’t tell you anything else about the object, it’s not clear I can do that. OK, if it’s a much more general situation, I have to write down Maxwell’s equations, and this is what I would write down. Write down J dot dS as a function of the coordinate here integrated over the area minus, OK, I would have to start from there from one of Maxwell’s equations.

好的，请注意，在我们的简化中，这变成了 IA，这变成了 IB。但是，如果我不告诉你其他任何事情，你必须从这里开始。这里会有一些不同的电流。你可能会有一些其他电流从这里流出，因为我里面可能会有一些电荷积聚。

All right, notice that this becomes IA, and this becomes IB in our simplification. But, if I don’t tell you anything else, you have to start from here. You will have some varying current here by point. You might have some other current coming out here because I may have some charge buildup happening inside.

如果电荷在灯丝内部积聚，那么我必须将 del q 乘以 del t，对，电流输入减去电流输出必须等于电荷积聚。哇，这在哪里，那在哪里？所以这是现实。这确实是我必须要做的。但我是怎么做到的？我是怎么做到的？关键答案是，作为工程师，当有疑问时，我们会简化。

If charge is building up inside the filament; then I would have to put del q by del t out here, right, the current in minus the current out must equal charge buildup. Whoa, where is this and where is that? So this is reality. This is really, really what I have to do. But how did I get there? How did I get there? The key answer is, as engineers, when in doubt we simplify.

记住，我们是工程师。我们人生的目标是建立有趣的系统。好吧，有些人是受金钱驱使。好吧，所以我们的目标是建立有趣的系统，造福人类。所以，只要我们能制造出好的灯泡，我们就很高兴。所以我们能做的就是说，看，我所关心的只是建立有趣的系统。所以我可以说，嘿，这东西太难了。

Remember, we are engineers. Our goal in life is to build interesting systems. OK and some are motivated by money. OK, so our goal is to build interesting systems and do good to humanity. So, as long as we can build a good light bulb, we are happy. So what we can do is we can say, look, all I care about is building interesting systems. So I can say, hey, this stuff is too hard.

让我们假设所有我们要考虑的系统都将这个值设为零。好的，换句话说，如果我取一个完整的物体，如果我取一个像电阻或电容这样的元件，整个元件周围的盒子，好的，我只想处理那些这个值为零的系统。你可以来打我，说，但为什么？为什么不呢？我为什么要这样做？

Let’s make the assumption that all the systems that we will consider will have this thing be zero. OK, in other words, if I take a complete object, if I take an element like a resistor or a capacitor, the box around the entire element, OK, and I want to just deal with those systems in which this thing is zero. You can come and beat me up and say, but why? Why not? Why am I doing this?

我说的是世界是任意的。我是一名工程师；我想建立良好的系统。通过进行这种简化，我消除了这种波浪线之类的东西。我不想处理它。我想让我的生活变得简单。所以这个归零了，因为，为什么？因为我说过，将来我只会处理那些符合这一事实的元素。我要严格约束自己。

And I am saying the world is arbitrary. I’m an engineer; I want to build good systems. By making this simplification, I eliminate this squiggle thing, and so on. I don’t want to deal with it. I want to make my life simple. So this is gone to zero because, why? Because I have said that in the future I will only deal with those elements for which this is true. I’m going to discipline myself.

我要严格要求自己只处理这些系统。好吧，麦克斯韦转过身来，你知道，对我生气之类的，但这很难。这就是我所说的在这里进行简化，这是我所做的简化之一。我给这个简化起了个名字。这就是所谓的集中物质学科。

I’m going to discipline myself to only deal with those systems. OK, Maxwell is turning around and, you know, mad at me and all that stuff, but tough. So this, what I’ve said about making a simplification here, and this is one of the simplifications I’m making. And I give a name to the simplification. And that’s called the lumped matter discipline.

好的，所以我说我只会处理那些如果我用黑框框起来就会成立的元素。如果这是真的，那么请注意，没有电荷积累。电流输入必须等于电流输出。啊哈！所以这变成了 IA。这变成了 IB。是的。好的，我现在可以处理 IA 和 IB 了。IB 和 IA 相等，因为这是零。

OK, so I’m saying I will only deal with elements for which if I put a black box around it, this is going to be true. And if this is going to be true, then notice, there is no charge buildup. Current in must equal current out. Ah ha! So this becomes IA. This becomes IB. Yes. OK, I can now deal with IA’s and IB’s. And IB and IA are equal because this is zero.

请注意，从这里到这里，这里有大量的深度。作为麻省理工学院的毕业生，你真的、真的需要理解我们为什么要进行这样的跳跃，然后去利用它，做一些很酷的事情。好吧，这使我们能够定义 I。我们有一个与元素相关联的唯一 I，用于表示流经该元素的电流。

Notice that there is a whole bunch of depth here in the jump from here to here. As MIT graduates, you really, really need to understand why it is that we made that jump, and then go and use that, and do cool things. All right, this allows us to define I. We have a unique I associated with an element for the current through the element.

我们仍然需要担心 B，我不会详细讨论它。课程笔记对此进行了一些讨论，教科书也是如此。因此，当德尔菲 B（磁通量变化率为零）时，V, AB 被定义。因此，如果我取该元素并取元素外的任何区域，这必定是正确的。你会说，为什么这应该是真的？一般来说，这不是真的。绝对如此。

We still have to worry about B, and I won’t go through that in detail. The course notes have some discussion of that and so does the textbook. So V, AB is defined when del phi B, the rate of change of magnetic flux is zero. So, if I take the element and I take any region outside the element, this must be true. And you say, why should that be true? That’s not true in general. Absolutely.

一般来说这不是真的。但是我，因为我选择这样做，我只会处理那些元素。我会约束自己。但这些只是那些符合这个原则的元素，而这个原则也是正确的。我要限制我的世界。我要为自己创造一个游戏场。你想玩，就遵守我的规则。好的，这就是所谓的集中物质纪律。

It’s not true in general. But I, because I choose to, I going to deal with only those elements. I will discipline myself. But these are only those elements for which this is true, and this is true. I’m going to limit my world. I’m going to create a play field for myself. You want to play; follow my rules. OK, and that’s called the lumped matter discipline.

因此，一旦你说我要坚持集中物质原则，这在你的元素内部是正确的。这在元素之外也是正确的。你可以定义 VA 和 VB，然后好事就会发生。好的，让我给你展示几个集中元素的例子。但请记住，我们所做的很大一部分是基于这两个假设。

So once you say that I’m going to adhere to the lump matter discipline, and this is true inside your elements. This is true outside the elements. You can define VA and VB, and good things happen to you. OK, let me show you a few examples of lumped elements. But remember, a large part of what we’re doing is based on these two assumptions.

为了简单介绍一下背景，我建议你翻到课程笔记的第 1 章，通读一遍，看看这件事是怎么发生的。因此，通过遵循集中物质原则，我们现在可以把物体集中起来。我们可以把灯泡集中到电阻器中。

And to just go through the background on that, I would encourage you to go to chapter 1 of your course notes and read through just as how this came about, that comes about. So, by doing that by adhering to a lumped matter discipline, we can now lump objects. We could lump a bulb into a resistor.

好的，说清楚一点，一定数量的集总物体，现在，宇宙将由集总物体组成。好的，在此之前，当他回家时，我们讨论了鸡蛋、煎蛋卷、灯泡和开关，但是一旦你来到麻省理工学院，在学习了 6.002 课程之后，你就会开始讨论集总元件，你知道，电阻器、电压源、电容器，遵循集总物质原理的微小物体。

OK, so to be clear, a certain number of lumped objects, and now, the universe is going to be comprised into lumped objects. OK, so before this, when he went home, we talked about eggs, and omelets, and light bulbs, and switches, but once you come to MIT, and after you’ve taken 6.002, you begin talking about lumped elements, you know, resistors, voltage sources, capacitors, little inky dinky objects that follow the lumped matter discipline.

好的，它们遵循非常简单的规则，分析它们所需的数学运算也非常简单。还有什么比 V 等于 IR 更简单的呢？那么，让我给你举一个有趣的集总元件的例子，然后给你展示几个非常难看的集总元件。好的。好的，所以你在这里看到的，所以我们用 VI 特性来描述集总元件。好的，你施加电压，测量电流。

OK, they stick to very simple rules, and the math that you have to do to analyze them is incredibly simple. What could be simpler than V is equal to IR? So, let me give you an example of interesting lumped elements, and then show you a couple of really nasty lumped elements. OK. OK, so what you see out here, so we characterize lumped elements by the VI characteristics. OK, you apply voltage, measure the current.

好的，我可以在这里绘制 I，在这里绘制 V，然后看看它是什么样子。好的，我可以通过 VI 关系来描述元素。我可以根据 VI 关系创建许多元素。让我给你看几个例子。对于电阻器，由于 V 与 I 成正比，而 R 是常数，所以我得到一条直线。

OK, so what I can do is I can plot I here, and V here, and see what it looks like. OK, I can characterize elements by their VI relationship. And there are a bunch of elements that I can create based on the VI relationship. So let me show you a few examples. So for the resistor, since V is directly proportional to I, and R is a constant, I get a straight line.

这是 I 轴，V 轴，这是电阻。我实际上有一个可变电阻，所以我要改变电阻值 R，曲线的斜率也会改变。好的，我改变了 R 的值，因为它是一个可变电阻，斜率也会改变，因为我的 R 不同。

That’s the I axis, the V axis, and this is the resistor. What I actually have is a variable resistor, so I’m going to change the resistance value, R, and the curve will also change slope. OK, I changed the value of R because it’s a variable resistor, and the changes slope because my R is different.

好的，接下来，让我介绍一下固定电阻，屏幕左侧的这个就是固定电阻。您会看到它的 IV 特性是一条给定斜率的线，斜率为 1 乘以 R，就是这样。我无法更改它。

OK, next, let me go to a fixed resistor, and this guy here on the screen to your left is a fixed resistor. And you see that its IV characteristic is a line of a given slope, 1 by R, and that’s it. I can’t change it.

第三，我还有另一个集总元件，称为齐纳二极管，您将在本课程的第四周看到它，齐纳二极管的特性如下：IV。如果我的电压通过齐纳二极管略微上升，电流就会急剧上升。但如果电压变为负，则不会有任何电流流入，直到电压超过阈值，此时我的电流开始增加。

Number three, I have another lumped element called a Zener diode that you will see in the fourth week of this class, and the characteristics for the Zener diode look like this: IV. If my voltage goes across the Zener diode goes up slightly, the current shoots up. But if the voltage becomes negative I don’t have any current flowing into it until the voltage passes on the threshold, at which point my current begins to build up.

好的，我可以稍微增加电压，结果显示电流又开始增加。这是另一个有趣的集总元件，称为齐纳二极管。让我们转到下一个称为二极管的元件。二极管如下所示：IV。当二极管两端的电压变为正值（大约 0.6 伏）时，电流开始急剧上升。

OK, so I can increase the voltage a little bit, and it can show that the current starts building up again. So that’s another interesting lumped element called a Zener diode. Let’s switch to the next one called a diode. So a diode looks like this: IV. As the voltage across the diode becomes positive, around .6 volts, or thereabout, the current begins to shoot up.

但是当电压低于 0.6 的阈值时，我的电流几乎为零。这是另一个称为二极管的集总元件。您将在 002 生活中开始使用这些元件来构建有趣的系统。下一个例子是热敏电阻。热敏电阻是一种电阻器，其电阻随温度而变化。

But when the voltage is below that threshold of .6, then my current is almost zero. It’s another lumped element called a diode. And you will begin using these elements in your 002 lives to build interesting systems. The next example is a thermistor. A thermistor is a resistor whose resistance varies with temperature.

好的，这是个非常昂贵的小吹风机，我要做的是向电阻器吹一些热风，你会看到它的值会根据我加热的程度而变化。所以当它冷却下来时，让我把它冷却下来，这样你就能看到它的温度下降了。我可以再吹一下。我可以整天这样做。这太有趣了。

OK, so this is a very expensive little hairdryer, and what I’m going to do is blow some hot air at my resistor, and you’re going to see that its value is going to change depending on how much I heat it. So as it cools down, let me cool it down, so you can see it’s coming down. I can zap it again. I could do this all day. This is so much fun.

好的，这是另一个有趣的集总元件。随着温度升高，其电阻会发生变化。下一个东西叫做光敏电阻。它是一个电阻器。它以前是一个电阻器；洛伦佐？哦，好的，没问题。所以这是一个光敏电阻。请注意，它几乎表现得像一个开路。但我要做的是给它照点光。

OK, so that’s another interesting lumped element. As the temperature rises, its resistance changes. The next thing is called a photo resistor. It’s a resistor. It used to be a resistor; Lorenzo? Oh OK, that’s fine. So this is a photo resistor. And notice that it almost behaves like an open circuit. But what I’m going to do is shine some light on it.

当我用光照射它时，它开始导电并变成一个具有一定值的电阻。就是这样。好的，这就是光敏电阻。现在我要给你们展示一个电池。注意，我们之前确实讨论过电池。我会给你们展示一个电池。所以在展示电池之前，先想一想，电池的 IV 特性应该是什么样的？IV。电池提供恒定电压。

When I shine light on it, it begins to conduct and becomes a resistor of some value. There you go. OK, so that’s a photo resistor. So now I’m going to show you a battery. Notice we did talk about batteries before. I’ll show you a battery. So before you show a battery, just thinking your own minds, what should the IV characteristic of a battery look like? IV. A battery supplies a constant voltage.

您知道您的小电池，AA 电池，1.5 伏特吗？那么，想想电池的 IV 特性在显示之前三秒钟应该是什么样的。这是我展示的，洛伦佐？这是一条直线。这是一块好电池。这是一条垂直的直线，但显示电压为 1.5 伏特左右。

You know your little cell, the AA battery, 1.5 volts? So, think of what the IV characteristic of a battery should look like for three seconds before it shows you. This is the one I showed, Lorenzo? It’s a straight line. This is a good battery. It’s a straight, vertical line, but says that the voltage is 1.5 volts, or thereabouts.

无论它作为理想电压源提供多少电流，它都有一个固定的电压 V，也不管通过的电流是多少。现在，我将向你们展示一个坏电池，坏电池是这样的。你们中的许多人都遇到过汽车电池没电的情况。当你去商店时，他们会检查你的电池。他们正是利用了这个原理，即没电的电池有电阻。

No matter what current it supplies as an ideal voltage source, it has a fixed voltage, V, and no matter what the current going through is. Now, I’ll show you a dud, a bad battery, and this is what the bad battery looks like. So, many of you have had your car batteries die on you. When you go to the store, they check your batteries. They use exactly this principle, that dead batteries have resistance.

顺便说一下，你看到这里有斜率。你想到的是阻力。好的，他们可以利用这个属性来判断你的电池没电了。所以那是一块没电的电池。最后，让我给你看一个灯泡。我们从一个灯泡开始，所以我需要以灯泡结束，好的，我们从一个灯泡开始，所以我需要以灯泡结束。你会看到，灯泡的行为就像一个电阻器。

By the way, you see slopes here. You’re thinking of resistance. OK, they can use this property to figure out that your battery is dead. So that’s a dead battery. And finally, let me show you a bulb. We started with a bulb, and so I need to end, OK, we started with a bulb, so I need to end with a bulb. And what you will see is that a bulb simply behaves like a resistor.

它的 IV 曲线看起来会像这样。好的，注意这是我的灯泡。你猜怎么着，它的行为就像一个电阻器。这是一种非常有趣的电阻器，所以我现在不会详细介绍。但请注意，它的 IV 特性就像一个电阻器。好的，这些是一些非常标准的集总元件。你要处理更多组集总元件、开关、MOSFET、电容器、电感器，还有一堆其他有趣的东西。

Its IV curve is going to look like this. OK, notice this is my bulb. And guess what, it behaves like a resistor. It’s a very interesting kind of resistor, so I won’t go into details for now. But notice its IV characteristic behaves like a resistor. OK, so those are some pretty standard lumped elements. You deal with a lot more sets of lumped elements, switches, MOSFETs, capacitors, inductors, a bunch of other fun stuff.

但在此之前，我想告诉你，不要对这种抽象狂热发狂。任何东西太多都对你有害。所以我要向你展示的是，抽象或模型只有在你在一组约束内工作时才有效。注意，我们已经有了这种心照不宣的握手，表示我们遵守纪律。

But before we do that, what I wanted to tell you, don’t go berserk on this abstraction binge. Too much of anything is bad for you. So what I’m going to show you is, abstractions or models are only valid provided you work within a set of constraints. Notice, we have already had this tacit handshake which said that we follow the discipline.

即使我们遵循了这一原则，物理元件的表现与理想集总元件的表现也存在一定范围。例如，我们将向您展示电阻器。它看起来像一个电阻器。我将继续增加它周围的电压。好吧，在某个时刻会发生什么？我只是继续这样做。

Even after we follow the discipline, there are ranges to how well physical elements can behave like ideal lumped elements. OK, for example, what we will do is show you the resistor. And it’s going to look like a resistor. And I’m going to keep increasing the voltage around it. OK, what’s going to happen at some point? I just keep doing that.

如果它是一个理想元素，如果你是一个理论家，你会说，哦，是的，曲线会一直延伸，直到我达到无穷大。但这是一个实际的电阻器，所以这里的人可以遮住你的眼睛或做点什么。好吧，所以你的抽象无法预测这一点。它所说的只是电流是安培。它无法预测热量、光线或气味。即使在实验室里，你也能闻到气味。你知道有人刚刚做了什么。

If it’s an ideal element, if you’re a theorist, you say, oh yeah, the curve will keep extending until I reach infinity. But this is a practical resistor, so people out here can cover your eyes or something. OK, so you’re abstraction can’t predict that. All it says is the current is an amp. It can’t predict the heat, light, or the smell. In the laboratory, even, you get the smell. You know what somebody has just done.

这就是集总抽象概念被打破的一个例子。所以，如果我真的相信我自己的 BS，任何东西都是集总元素。所以这是一个 pickle。pickle 是一个集总元素。我可以选择它作为集总电阻。但这是一个非常有趣的集总电阻。不要在家里尝试这个。这是一个标准的 pickle，你正在向其中注入 110 V AC。我向你保证，这是一个标准的 pickle。

So that’s one example of the lumped abstraction breaking down. So, if I really believe that my own BS, anything is a lumped element. So here’s a pickle. A pickle is a lumped element. I can choose it as a lumped resistor. But this is a very interesting lumped resistor. Don’t try this at home. This is a standard pickle into which you are pumping 110 V AC. I promise you, this is a standard pickle.

因此，它具有固定的电阻，但您的集中抽象无法预测漂亮的灯光和声音效果。好的，最后两三分钟我要做什么，所以请记住，不要被抽象所迷惑。这是有限制的。好的，你无法预测一切。好的，那是泡菜的味道。好的，让我给你预览一些即将到来的景点，并在最后几分钟向你展示另一个快速简化。

So, it has a fixed resistance, but your lumped abstraction cannot predict the nice light and sound effect. OK, so the last two or three minutes what I want to do, so remember, don’t get carried away by abstractions. There are limits. OK, you can’t predict everything. OK, that’s the smell of a pickle. OK, so let me give you a preview of some upcoming attractions, and show you one more quick simplification in the last few minutes.

那么，我们能做的就是，一旦我们构建了这些集总元件，我们就可以将它们连接到电路中。好的，我可以构建一个这样的电路。这是一个带有一堆电阻器的电压源。我可以用电线将它们连接起来，并构建一个这样的电路。我们可以问自己一个有趣的问题，在集总物质学科下，我们能对电压说些什么？

So what we can do, once we build these lumped elements, we can connect them in circuits. OK, so I can build a circuit, of the sort. So here’s a voltage source with a bunch of resistors. I can connect them with wires and build a circuit of the sort. One interesting question we can ask ourselves is, under the lumped matter discipline, what can we say about the voltages?

好的，如果我绕着这个环走，假设我的世界遵循集中物质定律，我能对这个环周围的电压说些什么呢？啊哈，又是麦克斯韦，对吧？所以，我可以写出麦克斯韦的适当方程来解决这个问题。好的，电压与 E 以及 E 点 dl 的积分和所有这些东西有关，对吧？所以这是适合使用的麦克斯韦方程。我想知道这里发生了什么。

OK, if I go around the loop, provided my world adheres to the lumped matter discipline, what can I say about the voltages around this loop? Ah ha, Maxwell again, right? So, I can write Maxwell’s appropriate equation to solve that. OK, voltages have something to do with E and your integral of E dot dl and all of that stuff, right? So this is the appropriate Maxwell’s equations to use. And I want to find out what happens here.

现在请记住，在 LMD 下，我做出了假设。好吧，我的世界，我的游乐场，德尔菲 B 的德尔 t 为零。通量变化率为零。因此，在这种情况下，我可以写下这个。我可以将这个线积分分解为电压源和两个电阻上的三部分，然后写下来。

Now remember, under LMD, I made the assumption. OK, my world, my playground, has del phi B by del t being zero. The rate of change of flux is zero. So, under these circumstances, I can write this. I can break up this line integral into three parts across the voltage source and across the two resistors and write that down.

好的，然后当我能做到的时候，现在右边是零，我可以简单地取这个。我知道这个元素上的 E 点 dl 就是 VCA。这是 VAB，这是 VBC 等于零。好的，所以当我假设 del phi B 乘以 del t 为零时，我绕着这个循环，应用麦克斯韦方程，我会发现什么？

OK, and then when I can do, is now that the right hand side is zero, I can simply take this. And I know that E dot dl across this element is simply VCA. This is VAB, and this is VBC equals zero. OK, so when I make the assumption that del phi B by del t is zero, and I go around this loop, apply Maxwell’s equations, what do I find?

我发现电压 VCA 加 VAB 加 VBC 的总和为零。这太棒了。现在，我可以对这个宝贝说再见了。我可以专注于这个家伙，说麦克斯韦方程，这个带有波浪线和 del 等东西的东西，可以简化为电路中环路中一组元件的电压总和为零。

I find that the sum of the voltages, VCA plus VAB plus VBC, is zero. That’s fantastic. So now, I could say hasta la vista to this baby here. And I can focus on this guy and say, Maxwell’s equations, this thing with squiggles and dels and all that stuff, can be simplified to the sum of the voltages across a set of elements in a loop in a circuit is zero.

好的，这就是基尔霍夫第一定律，KVL。好的，同样，在复习部分，你会看到基尔霍夫电流定律的应用，它来自等于零，并且进入节点的所有电流为零。因此，KVL 和 KCl 直接来自集中物质学科。你可以用它们来解决这样的电路。

OK, and this is called Kirchhoff’s first law, KVL. OK, similarly, in recitation section, you’ll see the application of Kirchhoff’s current law, which comes from this be equal to zero, and all the currents coming into a node being zero. So, KVL and KCl directly come out of the lumped matter discipline. And you can use those to solve circuits like this.

Lec 2 | MIT 6.002 电路与电子学，2007 年春季

Lec 2 | MIT 6.002 Circuits and Electronics, Spring 2007

17 年前 (2008 年 1 月 17 日) — 49:10 https://youtube.com/watch?v=2vHGYdepKLw

17 years ago (Jan 17, 2008) — 49:10 https://youtube.com/watch?v=2vHGYdepKLw

介绍

Introduction

早上好，好的。让我们开始吧。今天我们有一份讲义。这是你的讲义。对于那些还没有拿到的人，外面还有一些副本。一般来说，我在讲义中会省略大量的材料。这样，当我讲课时，你就可以腾出手来记笔记等等。所以，不要以为我讲的所有内容都在这里。

Good morning, OK. Let’s get started. We have one handout today. That’s your lecture notes. There’s some copies still outside for those who haven’t picked one up. In general, what I do is, in the lecture notes, I leave out large amounts of material. So, this will enable you to keep your hands busy while I’m lecturing and take down some notes and so on. So, don’t assume that everything that I talk about is on here.

请继续。好的，按照我的惯例，让我先快速回顾一下我们到目前为止所讲的内容。

Please follow along. OK, so as is my usual practice, let me start with a quick review of what we covered so far.

审查

Review

因此，我们主要做的是研究我们称之为块状物质学科的学科，它非常相似，让人想起物理学中的点质量简化。

So what we did primarily was looked at this discipline that we call the lump matter discipline, which was very similar, very reminiscent of the point mass simplification in physics.

这门学科，这套我们强加给自己的约束，让我们从麦克斯韦方程转向一种非常非常简单的代数方程形式。具体来说，这门学科有两种形式。

And this discipline, this set of constraints we imposed on ourselves, allowed us to move from Maxwell’s equations to a very, very simple form of algebraic equations. And specifically, the discipline took two forms.

块状物质

Lump Matter

一是，我们说我们将处理这样的元素，对于这些元素，在元素外部，磁通量的变化率为零，对于这些元素，我想要在元素内部充电的电荷的变化率为零。

One is, we said that we will deal with elements for whom the rate of change of magnetic flux is zero outside of the elements, and for whom the rate of change of charge I want to charge inside the element was zero.

所以，如果我拿任何元件，任何我称之为集总电路元件的元件，比如电阻器或电压源，并在它周围放一个黑盒子，那么我说的是里面的净电荷将为零。但一般来说情况并非如此。

So, if I took any element, any element that I called a lump circuit element, like a resistor or a voltage source, and I put a black box around it, then what I’m saying is that the net charge inside that is going to be zero. And this is not true in general.

我们将看到一些例子，例如，如果你选择某个元素的某个部分，可能会有电荷积聚，但在净内部，如果我把一个盒子围住整个元素，我会假设电荷的变化率为零。

We will see examples where, if you choose some piece of an element for example, there might be charge buildup, but net inside the, if I put a box around the entire element, I am going to assume that the rate of change of charge is going to be zero.

因此，它使我们能够创建集总电路抽象，我可以在其中获取元素，某种元素，可以是电阻器、电压源或其他任何东西，现在我可以归因于电压，某个元素两端的某个电压，以及流入该元素的某个电流 “i”。

So, what this did was it enabled us to create the lump circuit abstraction, where I could take elements, some element of the sort, this could be a resistor, a voltage source, or whatever, and I could now ascribe a voltage, some voltage across an element, and also some current, “i,” that was going into the element.

在我继续之前，当我标记跨过和流过元件的电压和电流时，我将遵循惯例。好的，惯例是，如果我按以下方式标记 V，那么我将为该元件标记“i”，作为流入正极的电流。这只是一个惯例。通过这样做，结果就是元件消耗的功率是“vi”，是正的。

And as I go forward, when I label the voltages and currents across and through elements, I’m going to be following a convention. OK, the convention is that I’m going to label, if I label V in the following manner, then I’m going to label “i” for that element as a current flowing into the positive terminal. It’s just a convention. By doing this, it turns out that the power consumed by the element is “vi” is positive.

好的，所以通过选择 I 以这种方式进入正极，元件消耗的功率将为正。好的，所以一般来说，即使只是遵循这个惯例，当我标记电压和电流时，我会标记通过正极进入元件的电流。

OK, so by choosing I going in this way into the positive terminal, the power consumed by the element is going to be positive. OK, so in general of even simply following this convention, when I label voltages and currents, I’ll be labeling the current into an element entering in through the plus terminal.

当然，请记住，如果电流朝这个方向流动，假设有一安培电流朝这个方向流动，那么当我计算电流时，“i”将为负数。好的，通过做出这些假设，即集总物质学科的假设，我说我能够极大地简化我的生活。

Remember, of course, if the current is going this way, let’s have one amp of current flowing this way, then when I compute the current, “i” will come out to be negative. OK, so by making these assumptions, the assumptions of the lumped matter discipline, I said I was able to simplify my life tremendously.

具体来说，它能让我采用麦克斯韦方程，并将其简化为一个非常简单的代数形式，该形式既有电压定律，也有电流定律，我称之为基尔霍夫电压定律和基尔霍夫电流定律。

And, in particular what it did was it allowed me to take Maxwell’s equations, OK, and simplify them into a very simple algebraic form, which has both a voltage law and a current law that I call Kirchhoff’s voltage law, and Kirchhoff’s current law.

KVL 简单地说，如果我有某个电路，并且我测量了电路中任何环路的电压，那么如果我查看任何环路中的电压，那么环路中的电压总和将为零。好的，所以我测量环路中的电压，它们的总和将为零。

KVL simply states that if I have some circuit, and if I measured the voltages in any loop in the circuit, so if I look at the voltages in any loop, then the voltages in the loop would sum to zero. OK, so I measure voltages in the loop, and they will sum to zero.

同样，对于电流，如果我取电路的一个节点，如果我建立电路，节点就是电路中多个边连接的点。如果我取一个节点，那么流入该节点的电流，流入节点的净电流将为零。

Similarly, for the current, if I take a node of a circuit, if I build the circuit, a node is a point in the circuit where multiple edges connect. If I take a node, then the current coming into that node, the net current coming into a node is going to be zero.

好的，如果我取电路的任意一个节点，并将流入该节点的所有电流相加，它们的净和将全部为零。所以，请注意，我所做的就是通过这种纪律，通过我对自己施加的这种约束，我能够从麦克斯韦方程式实现这一令人难以置信的飞跃，到这些非常非常简单的代数方程式，KVL 和 KCL。

OK, so if I take any node of the circuit and sum up all the currents going into that node, they will all net sum to zero. So, notice what I’ve done is by this discipline, by this constraint I imposed on myself, I was able to make this incredible leap from Maxwell’s equations to these really, really simple algebraic equations, KVL and KCL.

我向你保证，在 6.002 的剩余部分，如果你只知道这些，你几乎可以用这两个非常简单的关系解决任何电路。这实际上非常非常简单。这都是非常简单的代数，好吗？

And I promise you, going forward to the rest of 6.002, if this is all you know, you can pretty much solve any circuit using these two very simple relations. It’s actually really, really simple. It’s all very simple algebra, OK?

例子

Example

因此，为了给您展示一个例子，让我做一个小演示。

So, just to show you an example, let me do a little demonstration.

让我做一个小电路，为你测量一些电压，并向你展示电压确实加起来为零。所以，这是我的小电路。所以，我将向你展示一个看起来像这样的简单电路，让我们继续测量一些电压和电流。就需要记住的术语而言，这称为环路。

Let me build let me build a small circuit and measure some voltages for you, and show you that the voltages, indeed, add up to zero. So, here’s my little circuit. So, I’m going to show you a simple circuit that looks like this, and let’s go ahead and measure some voltages and currents. In terms of terminology to remember, this is called a loop.

所以如果我从点 C 开始，穿过电压源，到达节点 A，穿过 R1，再穿过 R2 回到 C，这就是一个循环。同样，这个点 A 是电阻 R1、电压源 V0 和 R4 连接的节点。好的，只要确保你的术语正确即可。

So if I start from the point C and I travel through the voltage source, come to the node A down through R1 and all the way down through R2 back to C, that’s a loop. Similarly, this point A is a node where resistor R1 the voltage source V0, and R4 are connected. OK, just make sure your terminology is correct.

所以，我要做的是，我会为你做一些快速测量，并向你展示这些 KVL 和 KCL 确实是正确的。那么，上面的电路，我可以找一个志愿者吗？有志愿者吗？你所要做的就是在黑板上写下一些东西。过来吧。好的，让我做一些测量，你为什么不把我测量的结果写在黑板上呢？我要做的是，让我在这里借一支粉笔。

So, what I’ll do is I’ll make some quick measurements for you, and show you that these KVL and KCL are indeed true. So, the circuits up there, could I have a volunteer? Any volunteer? All you have to do is write things on the board.come on over. OK, so let me take some measurements, and why don’t you write down what I measure on the board? What I’ll do is, let me borrow another piece of chalk here.

我要做的是关注这里的这个环路，关注这个节点并进行一些测量。好的，您看到上面的电路。好的，我得到从 C 到 A 的电压是 3 伏。那么你为什么不写下 3 伏呢？好的，下一个是 1.6。那就是，我正在做 AB，V_AB。好的，然后让我做最后一个。

What I’ll do is focus on this loop here, and focus on this node and make some measurements. All right, so you see the circuit up there. OK, so I get 3 volts for the voltage from C to A. so why don’t you write down 3 volts? OK, so the next one is 1.6. And so that will be, I’m doing AB, V_AB. OK, and then let me do the last one.

是 1.37。我猜测量结果一直是这样的。所以，写的是 V_AC。但现在没问题。不用担心。所以，谢谢你。我很感谢你的帮助。好的，在实验误差的约束下，我注意到如果我把这三个电压加起来，它们加起来正好是零。好的，接下来让我关注这里的这个节点。在这个节点，让我继续测量一些电流。

It is 1.37. The measurements, I guess, have been this way. So, what’s written is V_AC. But it’s OK for now. Don’t worry about it. So, well, thank you. I appreciate your help here. OK, so within the bonds of experimental error, noticed that if I add up these three voltages, they nicely sum up to zero. OK, next let me focus on this node here. And at this node, let me go ahead and measure some currents.

我现在要做的是将电压改为交流电，这样我就可以继续测量电流而不会断开电路。好的，这一次，您还会看到我进行的测量。所以，我这里有，我想您可以这样看。我这里有从 D 拉出的三根电线。这是节点 D，好吗？

What I’ll do now is change to an AC voltage so that I can go ahead and measure the current without breaking my circuit. OK, this time around, you’ll get to see the measurements that I’m taking as well. So, what I have here, I guess you can see it this way. What I have here is three wires that I have pulled out from D. And this is the node D, OK?

因此，我将三根电线接入节点 D，这样我就可以更轻松地测量一些东西。好的，所以大家祈祷我在这里不会看起来像个傻瓜。我希望这能奏效。所以，你大致会得到，那是多少，10 mV。好的，所以峰峰值大约是 10 mV，假设如果波形在左侧上升，则为正值。

So, I have three wires coming into the node D just to make it a little bit easier for me to measure stuff. OK, so everybody keep your fingers crossed so I don’t look like a fool here. I hope this works out. So, you roughly get, what’s that, 10 mV. OK, so it’s about 10 mV peak to peak out there, and let’s say that if the waveform raises on the left hand side, it’s positive.

所以，它是正 10 mV。还有另一个正 10 mV，所以是 20 mV。这次，它是负的，大概是 20，我猜是 20。所以，就电流而言，我得到的是 10，10，对不起，是正 10，正 10，和 20，加起来为零。但更有趣的是，我可以通过将这个电流测量探针直接放在节点上来向您展示同样的事情。

So, it’s positive 10 mV. And another positive 10 mV, so that’s 20 mV. And this time, it’s a negative, roughly 20, I guess, 20. So, I’m getting, in terms of currents, I have a 10, 10, I’m sorry, positive 10, positive 10, and a 20 that adds up to zero. But more interestingly, I can show you the same thing by holding this current measuring probe directly across the node.

请注意，此处进入此节点的净电流为零。好的，这应该只是向您表明 KCL 在实践中确实成立，而这不仅仅是我们想象出来的。所以，在我继续之前，我想指出另一件事。

And, notice that the net current that is entering into this node here is zero. OK, so that should just show you that KCL does indeed hold in practice, and it is not just a figment of our imaginations. So, before I go on, I wanted to point one other thing out.

第三个假设

Third Assumption

请注意，我写下了集中物质学科的两个假设，好吗？

Notice that I’ve written down two assumptions of the lumped matter discipline, OK?

块状物质学科有一个总体假设，这个假设至少在精神上与物理学中的点质量简化相同。有人能告诉我这个假设是什么吗？我没有提到的总体假设，你可以在附录第 8.2 节的笔记中读到，与点质量简化在精神上相同的总体假设是什么？有人知道吗？

There is a total assumption of the lump matter discipline, and that assumption is, in spirit, at least, shared by the point mass simplification in physics as well. Can someone tell me what that assumption is? A total assumption, which I did not mention, which you can read in your notes in section 8.2 in the appendix, what’s a total assumption that is shared in spirit with the point mass simplification? Anybody?

这里要做出的一个总体假设是，在本课程中我们将要研究的所有信号中，我们都假设感兴趣的信号速度、转换速度等都比光速慢得多。好的，我感兴趣的信号转换速度比光速慢得多。

A total assumption to be made here is that in all the signals that we will study in this course, we’ve made the assumption that the signal speeds of interest, transition speeds, and so on, are much slower than the speed of light. OK, that my signal transition speeds of interest are much slower than the speed of light.

请记住，如果物体开始以光速移动，运动定律、离散运动定律就会失效。好的，同样的道理，如果我们接近光速，我们的集总电路抽象就会失效。后续课程将讨论波导和其他分布式分析技术，这些技术可以处理接近光速的信号。

Remember, the laws of motion, the discrete laws of motion break down if your objects begin moving at the speed of light. OK, the same token here, our lump circuit abstraction breaks down if we approach the speed of light. And there are follow on courses that talk about waveguides and other distributed analysis techniques that deal with signals that travel close to speeds of light.

好的，那么我继续讲电路分析的方法一。

OK, so with that, let me go on to talking about method one of circuit analysis.

基本 KVL KCl 方法

Basic KVL KCl Method

这被称为基本 KVL KCL 方法。因此，仅基于这两个简单的代数关系，我就可以分析非常有趣和复杂的电路。方法如下。假设我们的目标是，给定一个这样的电路，我们的目标是解决它。好的，在本课程中，我们将做两件事：分析和综合。

This is called the basic KVL KCL method. So just based on those two simple algebraic relations, I can analyze very interesting and complicated circuits. The method goes as follows. So, let’s say our goal is, given a circuit like this, our goal is to solve it. OK, in this course, we will do two kinds of things: analysis and synthesis.

分析说，给定一个电路，你能告诉我关于这个电路的什么信息？好的，所以我们将求解现有电路中的所有电压和电流、元件间的电压以及流过这些元件的电流。综合说，给定一个函数，我可能会要求你去构建电路。好的，因此对于这里的分析，我们可以应用我想要向你展示的这种方法。

Analysis says, given a circuit, OK, what can you tell me about the circuit? OK, so we’ll solve existing circuits for all the voltages and currents, voltages across elements, and currents through those elements. Synthesis says, given a function, I may ask you to go and build circuits. OK, so for analysis here, we can apply this method that I want to show you.

这里的想法是，给定一个这样的电路，让我们找出所有与这些元件连接方式有关的电压和电流。因此，基本的 KVL 和 KCL 方法有以下步骤。第一步是写下元件 VI 关系。好的，写下所有元件的元件 VI 关系。

And the idea here is that, given a circuit like this, let us figure out all the voltages and currents that are a function of the way these elements are connected. So, the basic KVL and KCL method has the following steps. The first step is to write down the element VI relationships. OK, right down the element VI relationships for all the elements.

第二步是为所有节点写出 KCL，第三步是为电路中的所有环路写出 KVL。就是这样。只需继续写下元素规则、KVL 和 KCL，然后继续解决电路。所以，我们要做的是，当然是举个例子。

The second step is write KCL for all the nodes, and the third step is to write KVL for all the loops in the circuit. That’s it. Just go ahead and write down element rules, KVL, and KCL, and then go ahead and solve the circuit. So, what we’ll do, we’ll do an example, of course.

但是，作为复习，到目前为止我们已经研究了许多元素，对于电阻器，元素关系表明 V 等于 pi R，其中 R 是此处元素的电阻。对于电压源，V 等于 V 0。这就是元素关系。对于电流源，元素关系是，“i”只是流过元素的电流。

But, just as a refresher, we’ve looked at a bunch of elements so far, and for the resistor, the element relation says that V is pi R, where R is the resistance of the element here. For a voltage source, V is equal to V nought. That’s the element relationship. And for a current source, the element is the relation is, “i” is simply the current flowing through the element.

好的，这些是电流源、电压源和电阻器等设备的一些简单元素规则。让我们继续解决这个简单的电路。我要做的就是继续为您解决电路问题。好的，如果您翻到笔记的第五页，我将继续编辑这里的电路。

OK, so these are some of the simple element rules for the devices that the current source, voltage source, and the resistor. So let’s go ahead and solve this simple circuit. And what I’ll do is go ahead and solve the circuit for you. OK, if you turn to page five of your notes, I’m going to go ahead and edit the circuit here.

KVL KCl 法

KVL KCl Method

你可以在第五页的笔记上写下这些价值观。

You can scribble the values on your notes on page five.

好的，作为 KVL KCL 方法的第一步，我需要写下所有元素 VI 关系。因此，在此之前，让我先标记电路中所有未知的电压和电流。因此，让我将与电压源相关的电压和电流标记为此处。

OK, so as a first step of my KVL KCL method, I need to write down all my element VI relationships. So, before I do that, let me go ahead and label all the voltages and currents that are unknowns in the circuit. So, let me label the voltages and currents associated with the voltage source as here.

请注意，我继续遵循这一惯例，每当我为某个元件标注电压和电流时，我都会在元件变量电压之后显示流入元件变量正极的电流。所以这里我有 V 零和 I 零。让我在这里暂停五秒钟，向你们展示有时会发生的一个混淆点。

Notice, I continue to follow this convention where whenever I label voltages and currents for an element, I will show the current going into the positive terminal of the element variable, OK, after element variable voltage. So here, I have V nought and I nought. Let me pause here for five seconds and show you a point of confusion that happens sometimes.

人们经常会混淆与元素相关的变量和元素值。请注意，这里的大写字母 V nought 是该电压源提供的电压，而这里的名称 v nought 只是一个变量，我们用它来标记该元素两端的电压。因此，类似地，我可以将 v1 标记为电阻两端的电压，而 i1 是流过电阻的电流。

Often times, people confuse between what is called the variable that is associated with the element versus the element value. OK, notice that here, capital V nought is the voltage that this voltage source provides, while this name here, v nought, is simply a variable that we’ve used to label the voltage across that element. So, similarly, I can label v1 as the voltage across the resistor, and i1 is the current flowing through the resistor.

因此，我遵循惯例，即电流流入正极，这种标记方法称为关联变量纪律。我试图在有选择的情况下使用纪律这个词，好吧，在各种可能的选择中，你选择一个作为惯例。

So this method of labeling, where I follow the convention, that the current flows into the positive terminal is called the associated variables discipline. I was trying to use the word discipline in situations where you have a choice, OK, and of a variety of possible choices, you pick one as the convention.

好的，这里，按照惯例，我们使用关联变量规则，并使用该方法一致地标记电路中的未知电压和电流。好的，让我继续标记，v4、i4、i3、v3，v2 和 i2、v5 和 i5。我想就是这样。所以，我已经标记了所有未知数。因此，这些电压和电流中的每一个都是与每个元素相关的电压和电流。

OK, so here, as a convention, we use the associated variables discipline, and use that method to consistently label the unknown voltages and currents in our circuits. OK, so let me continue the labeling here, v4, i4, i3, v3 here, and v2 and i2, v5, and i5. I think that’s it. So, I’ve gone ahead and labeled all my unknowns. So each of these voltages and currents are the voltages and currents associated with each of the elements.

我的目标是解决这些问题。好的，就我们的解决方案而言，让我们按照我为您概述的方法进行操作。因此，作为第一步，我将继续写下所有元素 VI 关系。好的，作为第一步，我将继续写下所有 VI 关系。那么，有人能帮我说出电压源的 VI 关系吗？好的，很好。

And my goal is to solve for these. OK, so in terms of our solution here, let’s follow the method that I outlined for you. So, as the first step I am simply going to go ahead and write down all the element VI relationships. OK, so as a first step, I’m going to go ahead and write down all the VI relationships. So, can someone yell out for me the VI relationship for the voltage source? OK, good.

因此，v0 是大写的 V nought，也就是说，变量 V nought 等于电压 v0。同样，我可以写出其他的。v1 是 i1、R1。v2 是 i2、R2，等等。好的，我有一、二、三、四、五、六个元素。因此，我将得到六个这样的方程。第二步，我将继续为系统中的节点编写 KCL。因此，让我从节点 A 开始。

So, v0 is capital V nought, that is that the variable V nought is simply equal to the voltage, v0. Similarly, I can write the others. v1 is i1, R1. v2 is i2, R2, and so on. OK, and I have one, two, three, four, five, six elements. So, I will get six such equations. Step two, I’m going to go ahead and write KCL for the nodes in my system. So, let me start with node A.

因此，对于节点 A，让我将流出节点的电流视为正值。因此，我得到流出的 I naught，加上流出的 i1，加上流出的 i4，对于节点 A，它们的总和必须为零。然后，我可以继续处理其他节点，比如说，我处理节点 B。对于节点 B，我有流出的 i2。

So, for node A, let me take as positive the currents going out of the node. So, I get I nought flowing out, plus i1 flowing out, plus i4 flowing out, and they must sum to zero for node A. Then, I can go ahead and do the other nodes, let’s say, for example, I do node B. For node B, I have i2 going out.

这是正数，i3，并且 i1 也进来了，所以我得到 i1 等于零。好的，所以我有 1、2、3、4，我有四个节点。好的，所以我会得到四个方程。事实证明，第四个方程不是独立的。你可以从其他方程中推导出来。所以，我从中得到了三个独立的方程。然后我可以写 KVL。对于 KVL，我只需在这里循环。

That’s positive, i3, and i1 is coming in, so I get i1 equals zero. OK, so I have one, two, three, four, I have four nodes. OK, so I would get four equations. It turns out that the fourth equation is not independent. You can derive it from the others. So, I get three independent equations out of this. I can then write KVL. And for KVL, I just go down my loops here.

让我用这种方式完成第一个循环。好的，我使用了一个简单技巧，在完成这个循环时，你必须非常小心，确保你的减号和加号正确。否则你会陷入混乱。一旦你标记了它，你需要确保你所有的减号和加号都是正确的。

And let me go through this first loop here in this manner. OK, and a simple trick that I use, you have to be incredibly careful when you go through this in keeping your minuses and pluses correct. Otherwise you can get hopelessly muddled. Once you label it, you need to be sure that you get all your minuses and pluses correct.

因此，对于 KVL，我想要做的是，假设我从 C 开始，然后从 C 转到 A。对于 AI 转到 B，然后从 B 回到 C。好的，这就是我遍历循环的方式。我要遵循的技巧是，当我的手指穿过该循环时，我将把电压标记为我看到的该电压的第一个符号。

So, for KVL, what I’d like to do is, let’s say I start at C, and from C I’m going to go to A. For A I go to B, and from B I’m going to come back to C. OK, that’s how I traverse my loop. And, the trick that I’m going to follow is, as my finger walks through that loop, I’m going to label the voltage as the first sign that I see for that voltage.

好的，我要从 C 开始，然后往上走。我先打入电压源元件，然后打入它，我打入 V 零的减号。

OK, so I’m going to start with C, and I go up. I start by punching into the voltage source element, and then punch into it, I hit the minus sign for the V nought.

好的，我只需要写下负 V 零，然后加上，然后我经过，当我到达 A 并下降到 B 时，我打到 V1 的加号。所以，这是正 V1。然后我打到 V2 的加号，这样我就得到正 V2，也就是零。好的，很好。所以，这也符合你笔记中的内容。

OK, so I’m just going to write down minus V nought, plus then I go through and as I come up to A and go down to B, I punch to the plus sign of the V1. So, that’s plus V1. And then I punch into the plus sign of the V2, and so I get plus V2, and that is zero. OK, good. So, that matches what you have in your notes as well.

所以，这是第一个方程。同样，我可以遍历其他循环并写下每个循环的方程。好的，我喜欢遵循的惯例是，当我遍历循环时，我会写下我为该元素计算的第一个符号作为电压的符号。好的，如果您愿意，您可以做完全相反的事情，只是为了与众不同。

So, this is the first equation. Similarly, I can go through my other loops and write down equations for each of the loops. OK, and the convention that I like to follow is as I go through the loop, I write down as a sign for the voltage the first sign that I counter for that element. OK, you can do the exact opposite, if you want, just to be different.

但只要你保持一致，就没问题。好吧，同样，我可以有四个循环，所以有四个方程。同样，其中一个方程依赖于其他方程。所以我最终得到了三个独立方程。所以，我总共得到了 12 个方程。我得到了 12 个方程。

But, as long as you stay consistent, you’ll be OK. All right, so in the same manner here, there are four loops that I can have, so four equations. Again, one of them turns out to be dependent on the others. So I end up getting three independent equations. So, I get a total of 12 equations. I get 12 equations.

方程式

Equations

共有六个元件，OK，电压源和五个电阻器。

There are six elements, OK, voltage source, and five resistors.

因此，有六个未知电压和六个未知电流。因此，我有 12 个方程和 12 个未知数。好的，我可以把所有方程式都放在一个大曲柄上，然后坐在那里磨合。如果我真的很残忍，我会把这当作家庭作业问题，让你磨合、磨合、磨合，直到得到六个电压和六个电流。好的，它起作用了。

So, there are six unknown voltages, and six unknown currents. So, I have 12 equations, and 12 unknowns. OK, I can take all of the equations and put them through a big crank, and sit there and grind. And if I was really cruel, I’d give this as a homework problem, and have you grind, and grind, and grind until you get your six voltages and six currents. OK, it works.

好的，你得到了 12 个方程，这个方法就行得通了。但是，请注意，这是一个相当肮脏的方法。它相当肮脏。我得到了 12 个方程，即使对于像这样的简单电路来说，这也是一件相当痛苦的事情。然而，可以说，这个基本方法离麦克斯韦方程只有一步之遥，很简单。好吗？所以你要做的就是这堂课的剩余部分，我将向你介绍另外几种方法。

OK, so you get 12 equations, and this method just works. However, notice that this is quite a grubby method. It’s quite grungy. I get 12 equations, and it’s quite a pain even for a simple circuit like this. However, suffice it to say that this fundamental method is one step away from Maxwell’s equations, simply works. OK? So what you’ll do is the rest of this lecture, I’ll introduce you to a couple more methods.

一种是直观的方法，另一种称为节点方法，这种方法更正式一些，但我认为它比 KVL KCL 方法更简洁。

One is an intuitive method, and another one called the node method is a little bit more formal, but is much more, I guess, terse Than the KVL KCL method.

直觉

Intuition

方法 2。因此，课程笔记中要阅读的相关部分是第 2.4 节。本学期我将强调的事情之一是直觉。

Method 2. So the relevant section to read in the course notes is section 2.4. One of the things that I will be stressing this semester is intuition.

您会发现，当您成为 EECS 专业的学生，​​或者继续学习，或者如果您与您的助教或教授等交谈，您会发现他们很少真正开始应用正式的分析方法。好吧，总的来说，工程师能够查看电路并仅通过观察写下答案。

What you’ll find is that as you become EECS majors, and so on, and go on, or if you talk to your TAs or your professors and so on, you will find that very rarely do they actually go ahead and apply the formal methods of analysis. OK, by and large, engineers are able to look at a circuit and simply by observation write down an answer.

过去，我们通常会忽略这个过程，并告诉我们的学生，看，我们教你们所有的形式化方法，你们会发展自己的直觉并能够做到。我们这学期会尝试强调直觉方法，并尝试向你们展示直觉过程是如何进行的，这样你们就可以通过简单的检查快速解决许多这样的电路。

And usually in the past, what we have tried to do is kind of ignore that process and told our students, look, we teach you all the formal methods, and you will develop your own intuition and be able to do it. What we’ll try to do this term is try to stress the intuitive methods, and try to show you how the intuitive process goes, so you can very quickly solve many of these circuits simply by inspection.

好的，我将在这里向你们展示的方法就是这样一种直观的方法。我将其称为元素组合工具。对于许多简单的电路，你可以通过应用这种方法快速解决它们。

OK, so this method that I’m going to show you here is one such an intuitive method. And I’ll call it element combination tools. OK, for many simple circuits, you can solve them very quickly by applying this method.

成分

Components

这种方法的组成部分如下。我学习了如何组合一组元素。例如，我有一组串联电阻器，从 R1 到 RN。

The components of this method are these. I learned about how to compose a bunch of elements. So, let’s say, for example, I have a set of resistors, R1 through RN, in series.

好的，您可以使用 KVL 和 KCL 来证明这相当于一个电阻，其值由电阻的总和决定。好的，如果我有串联电阻，那么实际上它就等同于一个电阻，其值是所有电阻的总和。好的，您可以查看课程笔记以了解这一事实的推导证明。

OK, you can use KVL and KCL to show that this is equivalent to a single resistor whose value is given by the sum of the resistances. OK, so if I have resistors in series, then effectively it’s the same as if there was a single resistor whose value is the sum of all the resistances. OK, you can look at the course notes for a proof for derivation of this fact.

类似地，如果我有并联电阻，那么我将它们称为电导。

Similarly, if I have resistances in parallel, so let me call them conductances.

电导

Conductances

电导是电阻的倒数。如果电阻以欧姆为单位，则电导以姆欧姆为单位，MHO S。好的，所以电导是 G1、G2 和 G3。实际上，这相当于有一个电导，其有效值由电导之和给出。好的，并联电导相加，串联电阻相加。

A conductance is the reciprocal of a resistance. If resistance is measured in ohms, conductance is measured in mhos, M H O S. OK, so that’s the conductance is G1, G2, and G3. And effectively, this is the same as having a single conductance whose effective value is given by the sum of the conductances. OK, the conductances in parallel add, and resistances in series add.

同样，对于电压源，如果我有串联的电压源，那么它们就等于电压的总和。同样，对于电流，如果我有并联的电流，那么它们可以被视为单个电流源，其电流是各个并联电流的总和。让我们做一个简单的例子。让我们来做这个例子。假设我有一个看起来像这样的电路，还有三个电阻。

Similarly, for voltage sources, if I have voltage sources in series, then they are tantamount to the sum of the voltages. And similarly, for currents, if I have currents in parallel, then they can be viewed as a single current source, whose currents are the sum of the individual parallel currents. So, let’s do a quick example. So let’s do this example. So, let’s say I have a circuit that looks like this, and three resistances.

假设我关心的只是流过这根电线的电流 I。我关心的只是电流。当然，您可以继续写 KVL 和 KCL。您将得到四个方程，并且有四个未知数。您可以解它。但是，我可以应用我的元素组合规则，并使用以下技术非常快速地找出电流 I 是多少。

And let’s say all I care about is the current, I, that flows through this wire. All I care about is that current. Of course, you can go ahead and write KVL and KCL. You will get four equations, and there are four unknowns. And you can solve it. But, I can apply my element combination rules, and very quickly figure out what the current I is, using the following technique.

所以，我能做的是，首先，我可以拿这个电路来说。我可以把这两个电阻组合起来，并表明就电流 I 而言，这个电路与下面的电路 R1 等效。我取两个电导之和，好的，结果是 R1、R2、R3、R2 加 R3。然后，我可以进一步简化它，得到一个电阻，其值由 R1 加 R2、R3、R3 给出。好的，我只是在简化电路。

So, what I can do is, I can, first of all, take this circuit. And, I can compose these two resistances and show that the circuit is equivalent as far as this current, I, is concerned to the following circuit, R1. And I take the sum of the two conductances, OK, and that comes out to be R1, R2, R3, R2 plus R3. And then, I can further simplify it, and I get a single resistance, whose value is given by R1 plus R2, R3, R3. OK, I’m just simplifying the circuit.

现在，从这个电路中，我就可以得到我需要的答案。I 就是电压 V 除以 R1 加上。好的，所以在这种情况下，当我正在寻找单个电流时，我可以通过应用其中一些元素组合规则非常快速地得到答案。而且，我可以摆脱必须经过正式步骤的麻烦。

Now, from this circuit, I can get the answer that I need. I is simply the voltage, V, divided by R1 plus. OK, so in situations like this where I’m looking for a single current, I can very quickly get to the answer by applying some of these element combination rules. And, I can get rid of having to go through formal steps.

因此，一般来说，每当你遇到电路时，大体上都会尝试使用直观方法来解决它。只有当某种直观方法失败时才使用正式方法。即使在你的家庭作业中，总的来说，家庭作业也不应该是肮脏的。好吧，如果你在家庭作业中发现很多肮脏的东西，请记住你可能没有使用某种直观方法。好吧，所以要小心。

So, in general, whenever you encounter a circuit, by and large attempt to use intuitive methods to solve it. And go to a formal method only if some intuitive method fails. Even in your homework, by and large, the homeworks are not meant to be grungy. OK, if you find a lot of grunge in your homework, just remember you’re probably not using some intuitive method. OK, so just be cautious.

好的，现在让我继续介绍电路分析的第三种方法，第三种方法称为节点法。因此，节点法只是 KVL KCL 方法的一个具体应用，它会产生最终方程的更紧凑的形式。如果有一种你必须终生记住的方法，那么我会说只要记住这个方法就行了。

All right, so let me go on to the third method of circuit analysis, and the third method is called the node method. So, the node method is simply a specific application of the KVL KCL method and results in a much, much more compact form of the final equations. If there’s one method that you have to remember for life, then I would say just remember this method.

好的，节点方法是最简单的行业中的主力。好的，如果有一种方法你想始终如一地应用，那么这就是你要记住的方法。所以，让我快速为你概述一下这个方法，然后为你举一个例子。

OK, the node method is a workhorse of the easiest industry. OK, if there’s one method that you want to consistently apply, then this is the one to remember. So, let me quickly outline for you to method, and then work out an example for you.

节点法

Node Method

节点法的第一步是选择一个参考点或接地节点。这是接地节点的符号。

The first step of the node method will be to select a reference or a ground node. This is the symbol for a ground node.

接地节点只是表示我将表示该点的电压为零，并参考该点测量所有其他电压。因此，我将在电路中选择一个接地节点。其次，我想标记相对于接地节点的其余电压。因此，标记相对于接地节点的所有其他节点的电压。接下来，为每个节点写上 KCL。

The ground node simply says that I’m going to denote voltages at that point to be zero, and measure all my other voltages with reference to that point. So, I’m going to select a ground node in my circuit. Second, I want to label the remaining voltages with respect to the ground node. So, label voltages for all the other nodes with respect to the ground node. Next, write KCL for each of the nodes write KCL.

好的，但不要将接地节点写成 KCL。请记住，如果您有 N 个节点，节点方程将为您提供 N 1 个独立方程。因此，将节点写成 KCL，但不要将接地节点写成 KCL。然后，求解节点电压。假设我们标记电压时。我想将它们标记为 E 或其他。因此，求解未知节点电压。

OK, but don’t write KCL for the ground node. Remember, if you have N nodes, the node equations will give you N 1 independent equations. So, write KCL for the nodes, but don’t do so for the ground node. Then, solve for the node voltages. So, let’s say when we label voltages. I want to be labeling them as E something or the other. So, solve for the unknown node voltages.

然后，一旦我知道了与节点相关的所有电压，我就可以反向求解所有支路电压和电流。好的，一旦我知道了所有节点电压，我就可以继续计算出所有支路电压和支路电流。那么，让我们继续应用这种方法，并得出一个例子。再次记住，如果有一种方法你应该记住，那就是节点方法。

And then, once I know all the voltages associated with the nodes, I can then back solve for all the branch voltages and currents. OK, once I know all the node voltages, I can then go ahead and figure out all the branch voltages and the branch currents. So, let’s go ahead and apply this method, and work out an example. Again, remember, if there’s one method that you should remember, it’s the node method.

好的，如果有疑问，请始终应用节点方法，无论你的电路是线性的还是非线性的，它都会起作用，如果电阻器是在美国或苏联制造的，则无关紧要。好的，节点方法将正常工作，无论是线性还是非线性，好吗？所以，我要做的是建立一个我以前信赖的电路。

OK, and when in doubt, consistently apply the node method and it will work whether your circuit is linear or nonlinear, if the resistors are built in the US or the USSR it doesn’t matter. OK, the node method will simply work, linear or nonlinear, OK? So, what I’m going to do is I’m going to build a circuit that’s my old faithful.

这是我们的老方法，另外，我会通过添加电流源让它变得更复杂一些。所以，让我们来找点乐子吧。让我们来做这个。这是我的电压源，和以前一样。好的，我要做的是好玩，在那里添加一个电流源。而且，你可以说服自己，如果你继续应用 KVL KCL 方法，它真的会是一团乱麻。

It’s our old faithful, plus I’ll make it a little bit more complicated by adding in the current source. So, let’s go have some fun. Let’s do this. So here’s my voltage source, as before. OK, what I’ll do is for fun, add a current source out there. And, you can convince yourselves that if you go ahead and apply the KVL KCL method, it’ll really be a mess of equations.

好的，R1、R3、R4、R2、R5。好的，让我们按照我们的方法，只需在这里插上电源即可。让我们应用第一步。我选择一个接地节点。这是一个参考节点，我将从中测量我所有的其他电压。好的，现在对节点方法一无所知，试着用直觉来决定应该选择哪个节点作为接地节点。

OK, so R1, R3, R4, R2, R5. OK, so let’s follow our method and just plug and chug here. So let’s apply the first step. I select a ground node. It’s a reference node from which I’ll measure all my other voltages. OK, now without knowing anything about the node method, try to use intuition as to which node you should choose as a ground node.

请记住，您要将接地节点标记为电压零点，并测量相对于该节点的所有其他电压。好的，一个常用的技巧是选择一个连接了最多元件的节点作为接地节点。好的，特别是，您稍后会发现，选择一个连接了所有电压源（最大数量的电压源）的节点很有用。

Remember, you want to label the ground node with the voltage zero, and measure all the other voltages with respect to that node. OK, a usual trick is to pick a node which has the largest number of elements connected to it as the ground node. OK, and in particular, you will find out later it’s useful to pick a node in which all your voltage sources, the maximum number of your voltage sources are also connected.

好的，在本例中，我将选择它作为接地节点。好的，这是我的第一步。我选择它作为接地节点。我将把它标记为电压为零。第二步，我将标记相对于接地节点的其他分支的电压。好的，我要做的是在这里添加这个节点。所以我将把这个电压标记为 E1。这些是我的未知数。

OK, so in this instance, I’m going to choose this as my ground node. OK, that’s my first step. I chose that as my ground node. And I’m going to label that as having a voltage zero. Second step, I’ll label voltages of the other branches with respect to the ground node. OK, so what I’ll do is add this node here. So I’m going to label that voltage E1. These are my unknowns.

记住，节点方法，因为我的节点电压是未知数。因此，我将其标记为 E1。我将这个标记为我的未知电压，E2。这个呢？电压未知吗？不。我知道电压是多少，因为我知道这个节点的电压为 V0，高于接地节点。好的，请注意，要从这里到这里，我直接经过电压源。

Remember, node method, because my node voltages are my unknowns. So, I label this as E1. I label this one as my unknown voltage, E2. What about this one here? Is that voltage unknown? No. I know what the voltage is because I know that this node is at a voltage, V0, higher than the ground node. OK, notice that to go from here to here, I directly go through a voltage source.

因此，这个节点的电压为 V0。我只需写下 V0。好的，尝试简化您必须经历的步骤数，因此直接写下该节点的电压 V0。为了方便起见，我还会写下，我将使用电导。因此，我将使用 GI 代替 RI，并写下一堆节点方程。

And so, this node has voltage V0. And I’ll simply write down V0. OK, try to simplify the number of steps that you have to go through, so directly go ahead and write down the voltage, V0, for that node. What I will also do, is for convenience, I’m going to write down, I’m going to use conductances. So I’m going to use GI in the place of one by RI, and write down a bunch of node equations.

好的，第一步，我选择了接地节点。第二步，我标记了节点电压，E，好吗？我已经用两个步骤完成了这个。现在，让我继续，好的，让我继续应用第三步。第三步说继续对每个节点应用 KCL，在这些节点上，您有未知的节点电压。然后这将为您提供方程式。

OK, so step one, I’ve chosen my ground node. Step two, I’ve labeled my node voltages, E, OK? I’ve done that with two of my steps. Now, let me go ahead and OK, so let me go ahead and apply step three. And, step three says go ahead and apply KCL for each of the nodes at which you have an unknown node voltage. And then that will give you your equations.

那么让我先在 E1 处应用 KCL。那么，让我在 E1 处写下 KCL。我再做一件事。请注意，那里没有任何电流。好的，那么我该如何写 KCL？记住，根据块物质定律，KCL 只是说流入节点的电流总和再次为零。

So let me start by applying KCL at E1. So, let me write KCL at E1. I do one more thing. Notice, I don’t have any currents there. OK, so how do I write KCL? KCL simply says the sum of currents into a node is zero again, remember, by the lump matter discipline.

因此，如果我没有电流，那么我采用的技巧是，为了编写 KCL，我使用节点电压，并隐式替换节点电压，除以元素电阻，例如，所以我取节点电压，除以电阻，得到电流。好的，所以我隐式应用元素关系来获取节点电流。

So, if I don’t have currents in there, so the trick that I adopt is that to write KCL, I use the node voltages, and implicitly substitute for the node voltages, divide by the elemental the resistance, for instance, so I take the node voltages, and divide by the resistance, get the current. OK, so I implicitly apply element relationships to get the node currents.

这个例子很清楚，我取节点 E1，同样，对于流出的电流，我假设为正。因此，上升电流是 E1 减去 V 0，除以 R1，所以我乘以 G1。这就是上升电流。

So, the example that make it clear, so I take node E1 and, again, for currents going out I’m going to assume to have, to be positive. So, the current going up is E1 minus V nought, divide by R1, so I multiplied by the G1. That’s the current going up.

另外，流下的电流是 E1 减去零，其中接地节点电位为零，G2，OK，加上流向电阻 R3 的电流，也就是 E1 减去 E2，除以 R3。所以，E1 减去 E2，除以 R3，或乘以 G3 等于零。好的，看看我是怎么得出这个结果的？

Plus, the current going down is E1 minus zero where the ground node potential is zero, G2, OK, plus the current that is going to resistor R3, which is simply E1 minus E2, divide by R3. So, E1 minus E2, divide by R3, or multiplied by G3 is equal to zero. OK, see how I got this?

这只是 KCL，但为了得到电流，我只需取元件间电压差，除以电阻元件，即可得到电流。好的，所以我可以类似地在 E2 处写 KCL。所以，在 E2 处的 KCL，再次，让我向外走。

This is simply KCL, but to get my currents, I simply take the differences of voltages across elements, and divide by the element of resistance, and I get the currents. OK, so I can similarly write KCL at E2. So, at KCL at E2, again, let me go outwards.

因此，上升电流等于 E2 减去 V 零乘以 G4。向左电流等于 E2 减去 E1 除以 R3 或乘以 G3。下降电流等于 E2 减去零乘以 G5。并且，下降电流等于 I1。好的，你必须小心这里的极性。因此，所有流出的电流总和为零。这是此时流出的电流。

So, the current going up is E2 minus V nought multiplied by G4. The current going left is E2 minus E1 divided by R3 or multiplied by G3. The current going down is E2 minus zero multiplied by G5. And, the current going down is I1. OK, you’ve got to be careful with your polarities here. So all the currents going out sum to zero. And here are the currents that are going out at this point.

所以我接下来要做的是将常数项移到左边并收集我的未知数。所以，让我把它们写在这里。假设我在这里得到 E1，好的，从这个等式中，我有一个 V 零，G1，它在这里。所以，减去 V 零 G1 就到了另一边。然后，让我收集所有乘以 E1 的值。所以我得到，G1 就是一个例子。

So what I do next is I can move the constant terms to the left hand side and collect my unknowns. So, let me write them out here. So, let’s say I get E1 here, OK, and from this equation, I have a V nought, G1, which comes out here. So, minus V nought G1 comes over to the other side. And, let me collect all the values that multiply E1. So I get, G1 is one example.
