All right, let’s get moving. Good morning. Let me take a quick poll. So, how many of you have completed Lab 4. Completed Lab 4? Wow, that’s great. So, how many people have begun Lab 4? OK, well that’s good. I won’t ask the last question. OK so, well I hope you’re having fun with this lab. Lab 4 was designed to be almost like a mini project.

而且，它把整个课程的很多内容联系在一起。而且，它与人们在工业中设计的系统没有什么不同，这些系统用于各种设备，例如数字 CD 播放器等。其中会用到很多混合信号。好的，今天，我将继续讨论能量和 CMOS。

And, it sort of ties together a lot of the content of the entire course. And, it’s not unlike the kind of systems that people design in industry, in systems that go into a variety of devices like, say, for example, digital CD players and stuff like that. A lot of mixed signal stuff goes in. OK, so today, I’m going to continue with our discussion of energy and CMOS.

CMOS 将是我将介绍的一个新主题。所以，在上一节课中，我们花了相当多的时间讨论能量以及如何计算逆变器的能量。所以，让我从上次停顿的地方开始，今天我给了你们几页额外的笔记，只是为了把它与上一节课联系起来。现在，我要从第三页开始。

CMOS will be a new topic that I will introduce. So, the last lecture, we spent a fair bit of time talking about energy, and how to compute the energy of our inverter. So, let me start from where I left off, and I’ve given you a couple of extra pages of notes today just to sort of tie it to the previous lecture. Right now, I’m going to start off on page three.

上次我们看到的是这种类型的反相器，Vs，VIN，我们说，让我们研究一下这个反相器驱动负载电容 C 的情况。这个负载电容来自哪里？这个反相器可以驱动一个、两个、三个或四个其他更大的门，对吧？所以，这个 C 是所有这些反相器的栅极电容的集总值。

So, what we saw last time was an inverter of this sort, Vs, VIN, and we said, let’s study the situation where this inverter was driving a load capacitor, C. Where did this load capacitor come from? Well, this inverter could be driving one, or two, or three, or four other larger gates, OK? So, this C is lumped value of the gate capacitances of all of those inverters.

这可能还包括一些由线路电容等引起的元件。对于这样的逆变器，我们在上一节课中展示了平均功率的公式，这是与频率无关的静态功率，这被称为动态功率，它有一定的影响，它与你为电路计时的频率有关。所以，这与待机功率有关，与动态功率有关。

This may also include some component due to wiring capacitance and stuff like that. So, for an inverter like this, we showed in the last lecture that the formula for the average power was, so this was a static power independent of frequency, and this was called dynamic power, and it had some bearing, it’s related to the frequency at which you clocked your circuit. So, this was related to standby power, and this to dynamic.

所以，我还说我给了你一堆数字，这样你就可以计算一个包含 10^8 个门、1 亿个门、频率为 1 GHz 的芯片的功耗，以及一堆其他数字。C 被指定为 0.1 飞法拉。

So, what I also said is that I gave you a bunch of numbers so you could compute the power consumption of a chip that included 10^8 gates, 100 million gates, and at a frequency of 1 GHz, and a bunch of other numbers. C was given to be 0.1 femtofarads.

飞秒是 10^15。所以，F 是 10^9。VS 是 5V，对于这些数字，如果你把它们放到类似这样的位置，对于芯片上的 10^8 个门，平均功率将是这两个的 10^8 倍。所以，这将是 5 的平方，即 25，除以两倍。RL 被指定为 10 千欧姆，所以，两倍，10^4。这里我们有 CVS^2。所以，C 是 10^16，0.1 飞法拉。

Femto is 10^ 15. So, F was 10^9. VS was 5V, and for these numbers, if you plonk them down in something like this, for 10^8 gates on a chip, the average power would be 10^8 times these two. So, this would be five squared, which is 25, divided by twice. RL was given to be 10 kilo ohms, so, twice, 10^4. And here we had CVS^2. So, C was 10^ 16,0.1 femtofarads.

Vs^2 为 25，F 为 10^9。因此，如果您从这里的数字开始，最终得到的结果是这样的，10^8 乘以这里的这个。这是 1.25mW 加上这个最终是 2.5 微瓦。因此，这应该有点令人震惊。如果我取 1.25mW，并将其乘以 10^8，这意味着每个门的待机功率损耗为 1.25mW。

Vs^2 was 25, and F was 10^9. So, if you commence through the numbers here, what you end up getting is something that looks like this, 10^8 times this guy here. This is 1.25mW plus this guy ends up being 2.5 microwatts. So, this should come as a bit of a shocker. If I take 1.25mW, and multiply that out by 10^8, this says that each gate suffers a standby power loss of 1.25mW.

因此乘以 10^8，我得到 125kW，而这个家伙产生 250W。好吧，250W 是可以控制的。它仍然很高，而且为了让您不觉得这不合理，当 Pentium 4 首次推出时，它的功耗为 170W。好吧，您应该看到上面的散热器。实际上有一个巨大的散热器，散热器顶部内置有一个风扇。

So times 10^8, I get 125kW, and this guy yields 250W. OK, the 250W is manageable. It’s still high, and just so you don’t think that this is unreasonable, when the Pentium 4 first came out, it was consuming 170W of power. OK, you should see the heat sinks on there. There’s actually a huge heat sink with a fan built into the top of the heat sink.

好吧，今天它已经降到了更合理的数字，比如 100W 等等，但它刚推出时就在这个范围内。所以它很高，但并非不合理。但这当然是完全疯狂的。好吧，想象一下随身携带一台笔记本电脑，而这台电脑的功率是 125kW。那会很有趣。所以，显然这里出了问题。这意味着这里的这个门消耗 125kW，单个芯片上有 10^8 个这样的门。

OK, today it’s down to more reasonable numbers like 100W and so on, but when it came out it was in this range. So it’s high but not unreasonable. But this, of course, is totally wacko. OK, imagine carrying a laptop around, and the sucker is blowing 125kW. That’ll be fun. So, clearly there’s something wrong here. What this is saying is that this gate here consumes 125kW, there are 10^8 of these on a single chip.

好吧，所以我们显然必须对此采取行动，否则半导体行业将会失败。那么，有人有什么想法吗？你认为你可以做什么？你认为你可以对这个逆变器做些什么来让它看起来更好，把它弄坏？我能做什么？有人吗？有什么想法吗？你觉得呢？

OK, so we clearly have to do something about this, otherwise the semiconductor industry would fail. So, anybody have any ideas? What do you think you might do here? What do you think you might do to this inverter to make this look better, to bring it down? What can I do? Anybody? Any ideas? What do you think?

嗯，问题是，如果我看看这个 125kW，嗯，这里有一个 VS 项和一个 RL 项。所以，我可以增加 RL。好的，我可以让 RL 大四倍或八倍。这会稍微降低功率。有人能想到增加 RL 有什么问题吗？如果我把 RL 做得非常非常大，我会遇到其他问题吗？是吗？没错，逆变器的速度会变慢。

Well, the problem is that if I look at this 125kW, well, there’s a VS term here and an RL term here. So, I can increase RL. OK, I can make RL four times or eight times as large. That’ll bring the power down somewhat. Can anybody think of any problem with increasing RL? If I make RL really, really large, will I run into other problems? Yes? Exactly, the slowdown of the inverter.

请记住，逆变器的上升时间取决于我通过 RL 给这个电容器充电的速度。因此，如果我将 RL 做得非常大，我的待机功耗将从数百千瓦减少到仅仅数十千瓦。但我的门会像糖蜜一样慢。所以，显然这不是我想要的权衡。因此，我可以将电压降低到大约一伏。

Remember, the rise time of the inverter depends on how quickly I can charge this capacitor through RL. So, if I make my RL really large, I will consume less standby power from hundreds of kilowatts to merely tens of kilowatts. But my gates will run as slow as molasses. So, clearly that’s not a tradeoff I would like to make. So, I can reduce my voltage to maybe a volt.

但这只是将其减少了 25 倍，VS 平方。显然，这是行不通的。我必须以某种方式做其他事情，这将是今天讲座的主题。此外，我将在这个术语上停留片刻。所以，如果你看一下我们分发的 IBM ASIC 处理器的规格表，如果你还记得的话，我们谈到了每门每 MHz 0.006 微瓦的功耗。

But that just reduces it by a factor of 25, VS squared. So clearly, this is not going to work. I have to somehow do something else, and that will be the topic of today’s lecture. Also, I will dwell for a moment on this term. So, if you look at the spec sheet for the IBM’s ASIC processor that we handed out, if you recall, we talked about power dissipation of 0.006 microwatts per MHz per gate.

好的，现在您知道这是从哪里来的了。每 MHz，这是因为它是 f（功率）的倍数。其次，它是每个门，所以这是每个门的功率。因此，随着门的增多，功耗也会随之增加。在功率表达式旁边，它还显示电源电压在 0.7 到 1.3 的范围内。

OK, now you see where this is coming from. Per MHz, that’s because it’s a multiple of f, the power. Second is that it’s per gate, so this is the power per gate. So, as I have more gates, I just have that much more power dissipation. It also says power supply voltage in the range of 0.7 to 1.3 right next to the power expression.

所以，你明白他们为什么告诉你这些了，因为电压、频率和门的数量都进入了功率方程。好的，这个表达式非常简单，令人惊讶的是，它与人们用于芯片动态功率的表达式非常接近。好的，下一步，我想做的是，这个家伙，我们该怎么做呢？

So, you can see why they tell you all of that, because both voltage, and the frequency, and the number of gates come into the power of equation. OK, this really simple expression here, it’s amazing how close this is to what people use for the dynamic power in chips. OK, so as the next step, what I’d like to do is, this guy, what do we do about that?

好的，我们已经教过你如何用特定的方式构建门电路，但这根本行不通。那么，我们如何消除静电呢？我们如何消除静电呢？好的，为了做到这一点，让我们建立一点直觉。好的，直觉如下。假设我拿我的反相器。让我画出开启状态和关闭状态下的电路。

OK, so we’ve taught you to build gates in a particular matter, but it’s a non starter. So, how do we get rid of static power? How do we get rid of static power? OK, to do so, let’s build up a little bit of intuition. OK, so the intuition goes as follows. So let’s say I take my inverter. Let me draw the circuit both on the on state and in the off state.

因此，当 VIN 为高时，MOSFET 会导通，并产生电阻 RON，Vo 是输出电压。同样，当 VIN 为低时，Vo 会降低，因为 RON 远小于 RL。因此，该电压较低，而当 VIN 为低时，MOSFET 会关闭，因此这里出现开路。

So, when VIN is high, when VIN is high, I get the MOSFET turning on and has a resistance, RON, and Vo is the output voltage. Similarly, when VIN is low, so when VIN was high, Vo was low because RON is much less than RL. So, this voltage was low, while here, when VIN is low, the MOSFET is off, and so I have an open circuit out here.

由于开路，这里的电压会很高，因为 VS 会直接出现在那里。所以让我们调整一下，看看我们能否建立一些直觉来决定该怎么做。所以，当 VIN 较低时，我没有任何静态功率被耗散，因为我没有从 VS 到地的连接。好的，电流 i 为零。并且，VS 只会出现在输出端。

And because of that open circuit, the voltage here was going to be high because VS would simply appear there. So let’s tailor this and see if we can build up some intuition as to what to do. So, when VIN is low, I don’t have any static power being dissipated because I don’t have a connection from VS to ground. OK, the current, i, is zero. And, VS simply appears at the output.

之所以如此，是因为这里有一个开关。当它为低时，开关打开并切断从电源到地的路径。这是一个很好的情况。当 VIN 为高时，没有关闭的开关。相反，我得到了从 VS 到地的连接。好的，想想这里的这种情况。这里的见解是，想象一下如果我可以执行以下操作。

The reason this is so is have a switch here. So when this is low, the switch opens up and cuts the path from power to ground. This is a nice situation. Here, when VIN was high, there was no switch that turns off. Rather, I get a connection from VS to ground. OK, so think about this situation here. The insight here is, just imagine if I could do the following.

想象一下，如果我能以某种方式神奇地将 RL 提升到一个非常非常大的数字，如果我可以让它如此之高，以至于只有在输入很高的情况下，功率才会变得非常低，好吗？想象一下，如果我能做这样的事情。

Imagine if I could somehow magically elevate RL to be a very, very, very large number, if I could make this so high as to make the power really low only in the situation when the input was high, OK? So, imagine if I could do something like this.

想象一下，我可以打开这个家伙，RON，所以当 VIN 很高时，如果我可以，而不是在这里使用 RL，如果我可以让这个 RL 变为无穷大会怎么样？好的，在这种情况下，输出 VO 会很低。好的，这样做有很多好处。一个好处是，你看，我在这里打开了这个开关，所以我没有任何待机电流。好的，待机电流为零。

Imagine I could open circuit this guy, RON, so when VIN was high, if I could, instead of having an RL here, what if somehow I could make this RL become infinity? OK, so in this case, output VO would be low. OK, I get many benefits by doing this. One benefit is that, look, I have opened this switch here so I don’t have any standby current. OK, the standby current is zero.

第二个好处是我的输出被拖到地，对吧？在这里，我的输出是 VS 乘以 RON 除以这两个的总和。在这里，我直接连接到地，没有连接到电源 VS，因此我有一个不错的、稳定的低电平。所以问题是，我能得到这种情况吗？好的，这是一个关键的见解。

The second benefit is that my output gets dragged down to ground, OK? Out here, my output was VS multiplied by RON divided by the sum of these two. Out here, I have a direct connection to ground, and nothing to the power supply, VS, and so therefore I have a nice, solid low. So the question is that, can I get this situation? OK, that is a key insight.

想象一下，当这个为高电平时，我可以让它打开，就像当这个为低电平时，我可以让它打开一样。好的，想想看。直觉告诉我，我需要的不是这里的电阻器，而是像这里的 MOSFET 一样的东西。所以，我这里有一个 MOSFET，当 VIN 为低电平时，它会关闭。好的，如果我做了互补的事情会怎么样？

So, imagine that somehow, when this was high, I could get this to open up, much like when this was low, I got this to open up. OK, so think about it. So, the intuition is that what I need instead of a resistor here, what if I have something like the MOSFET that I have here? So, I have a MOSFET here that turned off when VIN was low. OK, what if I did the complementary thing?

如果我在这里放入某种 MOSFET，当 VIN 较高时，它会关闭吗？好的，就像这里的 VIN 较低时关闭的 MOSFET 一样，想象一下，如果我能找到一个当 VIN 较高时可以关闭的设备？好的，这个会打开，但这个会关闭。因此，该设备的行为必须与该设备互补。

What if I put in some kind of MOSFET here that would turn off when VIN was high? OK, so, much like the MOSFET turned off when VIN was low down here, imagine if I could find a device that could turn off when VIN was high? OK, this would be on, but this would be off. So the behavior of this device would have to be complementary to this device.

因此，我们需要某种开关来引入这种具有略微不同属性的新型小型 MOSFET 器件，让我快速为您回顾一下我们所知道的 MOSFET 的属性，所以我们的 N 通道 MOSFET（也称为 NFET）就是我们一直以来看到的，它是这样绘制的。我有一个栅极；我有一个漏极；我有一个源极。

So, we need some sort of a switch to introduce this new, little MOSFET device with slightly different properties, let me quickly review for you the properties of the MOSFET that we know about, so our N channel MOSFET, also called the NFET, this is what we’ve been seeing all this while, is drawn like this. I have a gate; I have a drain; I have a source.

当 VGS 大于或等于 VT 时，该器件导通，当 VGS 小于 VT 时，该器件截止。您之前见过，这没什么新鲜的。因此，我需要的是一种以互补方式运行的器件。因此，该器件是 P 通道 MOSFET。

And this guy is on when VGS is greater than or equal to VT, OK, and off when VGS is less than VT. You saw this before, OK, nothing new here. So, what I need is a device that behaves in a complementary manner. OK, so the device is a P channel MOSFET.

顺便说一句，我必须指出，直到 1983 年到 1984 年，直到 80 年代初，芯片的设计基本都是这样，使用 NFET 作为开关（如下所示），并使用各种不同类型的设备作为电阻器。好吧，那时技术开始朝着我将要讨论的这种新技术发展，这大大降低了功耗。

By the way, I must point out, till about 1983 84 until the early ’80s, that’s exactly pretty much how chips were designed, OK, using an NFET for the switch looking down here, and a variety of different kinds of devices to be used as resistors. OK, that’s when technology began moving towards this new kind of technology I’m going to talk about, and that dramatically reducing the power consumed.

然后，P 通道 MOSFET 诞生了，这个东西叫做 PFET。它是一种互补器件，如下所示。好的，这里的区别是，为了显示它是互补的，我在这里画了一个小圆圈。它有一个栅极。

And, the P channel MOSFET was created, and this guy’s called the PFET. It’s a complementary device that looks as follows. OK, the difference here is that, to show this is complementary, I’ll put a little circle here. It has a gate.

为了让事情更清楚一点，翻转漏极和源极端子，这个家伙在 NFET 器件的这个特殊阈值电压下开启，让我在这里放一个 N，表示这是 N 通道器件的 VT。对于这个家伙，当 VGS 大于某个电压时，这个家伙就会开启。因此，VTN 可以是 1 伏。因此，VGS 大于 1。这个家伙开启了。

Just to make things a little clearer, flip the drain and source terminals, and this guy is on at a distinguished threshold voltage of this with the NFET device, let me put an N here to say that this is the VT for the N channel device. And for this guy, this guy came on when VGS was greater than some voltage. So, VTN could be, for example, one volt. So, VGS was more than one. This turned on.

在这种情况下，我希望当 VGS 低于或远低于源电压时，它就会打开。好的，所以当栅极电压较高时，这个家伙就会打开。当栅极电压明显低于源电压时，这个家伙应该打开，只是互补行为。好的，所以当 VGS 小于或等于 VTP 时。

In this case, I wanted this to turn on when VGS is some value which is lower than, or much lower than, the source voltage. OK, so this guy turns on when the gate voltage is higher. This guy should turn on when the gate voltage is significantly lower than the source voltage, just the complementary behavior. OK, so when VGS is less than or equal to VTP.

在这种情况下，PMOS 器件的阈值电压，例如，可能是 1V。这意味着，如果源极电压为 5V，那么如果栅极电压低于 4V，该器件就会开启。因此，这是 5。如果栅极电压低于 4V，该器件就会开启。

And in this case, the threshold voltage for the PMOS device, say, just as an example, maybe 1V. So this means that if the source is at, say, 5V, OK, then this device would turn on if the gate, for example, using that example was less than 4V. So, this is five. If the gate fell below 4V, this guy would turn on.

在这种情况下，请记住，如果源电压为零，则栅极必须大于 1V 才能打开。在这种情况下，如果源电压为 5，则栅极必须小于 4V 才能打开。然后，栅极关闭。好的，所以这是一个互补设备，我假设它以互补的方式运行。

In this situation, remember, if this was at zero, the gate would have to be greater than 1V to turn on. In this situation, the gate has to be less than 4V if the source was at five to turn on. And, it’s off. OK, so this is a complementary device that I postulate that behaves in a complementary manner.

因此，栅极电压上升，这个东西就打开了，在这种情况下，当栅极电压降至源电压以下时，这个东西就打开了。好吧，所以当栅极电压上升时，在这种特定情况下打开，当栅极电压下降时，栅极就打开了，并显示出一些电阻。在这种情况下，电阻就是 RON。为了表明它是 N 通道，我称其为 N。

So, the gate voltage rises, this guy turns on, and in this situation, when the gate voltage drops below the source voltage, this guy turns on. OK, so when there’s a rising guy that turns on in this particular situation when it falls, the gate turns on and shows some resistance. In this case, the resistance would be RON. And to show that it’s N channel, let me say N.

在这种情况下，当它打开时，电阻将是 RONp，代表 P 通道。好的，现在考虑逆变器的以下电路。因此，我放置了一个互补设备来代替我的电阻器，好的，就是这样。所以我在这里所做的就是用一个与 N 通道 MOSFET 互补的 MOSFET 替换我的电阻器。所以这是我的栅极，我的漏极。这是我的源极，我的栅极，我的源极和我的漏极。

And in this case, the resistance, when it turns on, would be RONp to represent P channel. OK, so now consider the following circuit for the inverter. So, instead of my resistor, I put a complementary device, OK, and that’s it. So all I’ve done here is replace my resistor with a MOSFET that behaves complementary to the N channel MOSFET. So this is my gate, my drain. This is my source, my gate, my source, and my drain.

好的，这个叫做上拉，这个叫做下拉。好的，原因是这个在打开时将输出拉到地，而这个在打开时将把这个节点拉到 VS。因此，我根据 VIN 是高还是低来将其拉低或拉高。那么，让我们看看这两种情况。

OK, and this guy is called a pull up, and this guy is called a pull down. OK, and the reason is that this guy pulls the output to ground when it’s turned on, while this guy, when switched on, will pull this node up to VS. So, I pull it down or pull it up based on when the VIN is high or low. So, let’s look at the two situations.

举个例子，我的 VS 为 5V，假设 VIN 在一种情况下为 5V，另一种情况下为 0V。我们来画出这两种情况下的等效电路。当 VIN 为高时，我得到的是通常的电路。当 VIN 为高时，这个 MOSFET，和前面一样，当 VIN 为 5V 时，下面的 N 通道 MOSFET 导通，因此我这里有一个 RON 电阻。

So, let’s say, as an example, my VS is 5V, and let’s say VIN in one situation being 5V, and another situation being equal to 0V. Let’s draw the equivalent circuit in both these cases. So, when VIN is high, I have my usual circuit. When VIN is high, this MOSFET, as before, when VIN is 5V, the N channel MOSFET below is turned on, and so I have an RON resistance here.

但请记住，VIN 为 5，VS 为 5V，那么这个 P 通道 FET 的源极和栅极之间的电压现在相等，即 5 和 5。好的，所以这个会关闭。这就是我得到的电路。输出适当低。在这种情况下，如果 VIN 为零，会发生什么？这是我的输出。如果 VIN 为 0V，则下部设备关闭。这是零。这是零。

But remember, VIN is 5, and VS is 5V, then the voltage across the source and the gate of this P channel FET is now equal, five and five. OK, so this one would turn off. And that’s the circuit that I get. The output is suitably low. In this situation, if VIN is zero, what happens in this situation? Here’s my output. If VIN is 0V, the lower device turns off. This is zero. This is zero.

这个家伙关闭了，这就是 N 通道 MOSFET 的情况。这个家伙怎么样？这里发生了什么？这是 5。让我说一下，这是 5V。好的，VIN 为 0V。好的，因此，它的 GS 为 5V。如果这是零，这是五，G、源极和漏极，GS 为 5V，并且 5V 明显小于我们示例中的阈值 1V。

This guy turns off, and that’s the situation for the N channel MOSFET. How about this guy here? What happens here? This is at 5. So let me just, this is at 5V. OK, and VIN is at 0V. OK, so therefore, the GS of this is 5V. If this is zero and this is five, G, source, and drain, GS is 5V, and 5V is significantly less than the threshold 1V in our example.

所以，这个会打开。如果这个打开，我最终得到的是 RONp。所以，当这个启动时，它会将输出拉高，VO 也会变高。所以，我所做的就是用一个互补设备替换我的电阻器，当输入为高时，它会关闭，当输入为低时，它会打开。

So, this one will switch on. And if this one switches on, what I end up getting is RONp out there. So, when this one kicks in, it pulls the output high and VO goes high. So, all I’ve done is replaced my resistor with a complementary device, which switches off when the input is high, and switches on when the input is low.

它的美妙之处在于，假设所有设备都是理想的，在任何时候，输出之间都不会发生短路，从输出到地、从电源到地，都不会有电流路径，好的，我已经关闭了这个或者关闭了这个。

And the beauty of this is that at no point, assuming all the devices are ideal here, at no point do I have a short circuit between the output, do I have a current path from the output to the ground from the supply to ground, OK, I have this turned off or this turned off.

因此，这种涉及 PMOS 晶体管和 N 通道晶体管的逻辑被称为 CMOS 逻辑，好吧，它被称为互补 MOS 逻辑。这就是 CMOS 的由来。好吧，我相信你在很多地方都读到过，当今大多数数字芯片都使用 CMOS 技术。

So, this type of logic involving a PMOS transistor here, and the N channel transistor here is called CMOS logic for, OK, it’s called complementary MOS logic. That’s what CMOS comes from. OK, so I’m sure you’ve read in a number of places that most digital chips today use CMOS technology.

它来自互补 MOS，互补来自使用互补晶体管：N 通道、P 通道，高电平时打开，高电平时关闭，低电平时关闭，低电平时打开。好的，它们完全是互补的。好的，所以您在这里看到的是过去二十年、二十年来数字行业的主力，CMOS 逻辑。

It comes from complementary MOS, and complementary comes from the use of complementary transistors: N channel, P channel, turns on when high, turns off when high, turns off when low, turns on when low. OK, that’s exactly complementary to each other. OK, so what you’ve seen here has been the workhorse of the digital industry for the past two decades, 20 years, CMOS logic.

好吧，甚至英特尔最先进的芯片也有一个看起来一模一样的逆变器。好吧，如果你计算一下当今宇宙中的所有逆变器，我会说其中很大一部分看起来都一模一样，没有区别，就是这么简单。所以，关键在于没有从电源到地面的路径，所以根据这个模型，我没有消耗任何待机功率。

OK, and even the most advanced chip from Intel has an inverter that looks exactly like that. OK, if you count all the inverters in the universe today, I would say a significant fraction of those look exactly like that, no difference, just so simple. So, the key with something like that is there is no path from the power supply to the ground, and so by that model, I did not consume any standby power.

好的，在理想模型中，我的待机功率为零。那么，让我们计算一下 P。那么，P 动态是多少？让我们使用上节课中采用的方法，绘制等效电路，然后计算功率。好的，我将模拟以下情况，并假设我驱动电容负载 C。

OK, my standby power in that idealized model is zero. So, let’s compute P. So, what is P dynamic? Let’s use the method that we adopted in the last lecture, and draw the equivalent circuit, and compute the power. OK, so I’m going to model the following situation, and assume that I drive a capacitive load, C.

好的，作为输入，就像我上次做的那样，我假设我有一些输入电压 VIN，如下所示。周期时间 T，频率为 1/t，我假设这是 T1，这是 T2。好的，我假设 T1 和 T2 都比相应的时间常数大得多。

OK, and as an input, as I did the last time, I’m going to assume I have some input voltage, VIN, that looks like this. The cycle time, T, and the frequency is 1/t, and let me assume that this is T1, and this is T2. OK, and I’m assuming that T1 and T2 are both much larger than the respective time constants.

好的，这里的放电时间常数是 C RONn，相关电阻是 RONp。充电时间常数是 RONp 乘以 C。好的，因此假设 T1 和 T2 远大于这两个值。因此，除了功率优势之外，使用 CMOS 逻辑与使用 NMOS 相比还有另一个优势。

OK, the time constants when, for discharging here, is C RONn, and here the relevant resistance is RONp. The charging time constant is RONp times C. OK, so T1 and T2 are assumed to be much greater than these two. So when you look at this, there’s one other benefit besides the power benefit, OK, of using CMOS logic compared to using NMOS.

好吧，它不仅降低了我的待机功耗，而且还有另一个显著的优势，几乎与这种 CMOS 技术的功耗优势相当。有人有什么想法吗？有什么优势？直觉告诉你什么？CMOS 会比 NMOS 更快还是更慢？为什么？没错。

OK, it not only cuts out my standby power, but there is another significant advantage which is almost equal to the power advantage of this kind of CMOS technology. Anybody have any ideas? What’s the advantage? What does intuition tell you? Is CMOS going to be faster or slower than NMOS? Why? That’s right.

这里的关键是，我之前向您展示的 NMOS 设计相对较慢，因为我花了一段时间从 RL 给负载电容充电。在这种情况下，RL 会变得非常非常小；它是 RONp。它与 RONm 的量级大致相同。

The key here is that the NMOS design I showed you earlier was relatively slow because it took me a while to charge up the load capacitor from RL. In this situation, RL will become really, really small; it’s RONp. It’s roughly the same magnitude as RONm.

好的，如果这两个导通电阻大致相等且较小，则上升时间将与下降时间处于同一数量级，这使得它比 NMOS 快得多。在 NMOS 中，我的时间常数是 RLC，RL 相当大。在这种情况下，它是 RONp C，RONp 可以做得非常小，因为当它关闭时，这里的电阻是无穷大。

OK, if so both of these on resistances are more or less equal and small, then the rise time will be of the same order of magnitude as the fall time, which makes this much faster than the NMOS. In NMOS, my time constant was RLC, and RL was pretty large. In this case it’s RONp C, and RONp can be made to be very small because when it’s switched off, the resistance here is infinity.

因此，在这种情况下，如果我假设 T1 和 T2 远大于各自的时间常数，我就可以继续绘制等效电路。所以，这是 VS。所以，对于充电，假设这个是 1，或者高。所以，我让 VS 通过电阻 RONp 连接到电容器，这个东西是一个开关。

So, in this situation, if I assume T1 and T2 are much larger than the respective time constants, I can go ahead and draw my equivalent circuit. So, here’s VS. So, for charging up, let’s say this one is going to a one, or to a high. So, I have VS going through a resistor, RONp, to a capacitor, and this thing is a switch.

所以我有一个理想开关 RONp，连接到一个电容器 C，这是我的 V 输出节点，好的，所以它是 VS 通过一个电阻，即理想开关 RONp，连接到一个电容器 C。这是一个充电电路。对于放电，我有 C，通过一个理想开关 RONn 放电。所以，在这种情况下，我有一个理想开关 RONn。好的，这就是类似这样的等效电路。

So I have RONp, an ideal switch, going to a capacitor, C, this is my V out node, OK, so it’s VS going through a resistance, RONp, an ideal switch, to a capacitor, C. That’s a charging circuit. For discharging, I have C, discharging through an ideal switch with RONn. So, this situation, I have an ideal switch, RONn. OK, so that’s the equivalent circuit for something like this.

因此，在这个电路中，在 T1 期间，这个家伙关闭，而这个家伙打开，在 T1 期间打开，否则关闭。这个家伙在 T2 期间打开，否则关闭。好的，想象一下，这个家伙打开，这个家伙关闭，这个家伙打开，这个家伙关闭，好吗？请记住，这正是我在上一节课中分析过的电路，结果由 v 双星号给出。

So, in this circuit, during T1, this guy’s off, and this guy’s on, on during T1, and off otherwise. This guy is on during T2, and off otherwise. OK, so just imagine, this guy switches on, this guy switches off, this guy switches on, this guy switches off, OK? And remember, this is exactly the circuit I had analyzed last time in the last lecture, and the result given by v double asterisk.

结果就是平均功率 CVS^2f。这就是我们用来计算动态功率 CVS^2f 的确切电路。好的，我们完成了。这是怎么发生的？这是因为直觉告诉我，我正在给电容器充满电，然后我通过另一侧给电容器放电，好的，我在充电和放电期间在这两个电阻中消耗功率，耗散功率。

And that result was simply average power being CVS^2f. That’s the exact circuit we used to compute the dynamic power, CVS^2f. OK, so we’re done. And how did this come about? This came about because the intuition here is that I’m charging up the capacitor fully, and then I’m discharging the capacitor through this other side, OK, and I’m consuming power, dissipating power, in these two resistances during charge up and during the discharge.

一半的电量在充电过程中消耗，另一半在放电过程中消耗。因此，我想在这里回过头来计算几个数字，看看即使有了这个表达式，随着我们进入下一个十年，生活也会变得非常棘手。好的，对于我们之前的例子，我们假设 10^8 门，F=1 GHz，C=0.1 飞法拉，VS 为 5V，我不再需要 RL。

Half the power gets consumed during charge up, and half during the discharge. So, I’d like to go back to doing a few numbers here, and taking a look at how, even with this expression, life can get pretty thorny as we go ahead into the next decade. OK, so for our previous example, we assumed that 10^8 gates, F=1 GHz, C=0.1 femtofarads, VS was 5V, and I don’t need RL anymore.

好的，为什么这里没有任何电阻元件？这里没有电阻元件是因为该电路消耗的功率与这些电阻无关，前提是 T1 和 T2 足够长，比两个时间常数 RONp C 和 RONn C 长得多。好的，所以我的方程式中不再有 RL。我没有任何待机功率。

OK, why is it that I don’t have any resistance component here? I don’t have it here because the power consumed by this circuit is independent of those resistances, provided T1 and T2 are long enough, are much longer than the two time constants, RONp C, and RONn C. OK, so I don’t have RL in my equation anymore. I don’t have any standby power.

因此，基于此计算，我上面所做的计算表明，每个门需要 2.5 微瓦，而对于 10^8 个门，对于具有 10^8 个门的芯片，需要 250W。因此，如果您可以转到笔记的第八页，我想详细讨论一下这个问题。让我详细讨论一下这个问题，并就一些事情发表意见。

So, based on this calculation, the calculation I did up there showed that I had 2.5 microwatts per gate, and for 10^8 gates I had 250W for a chip with 10^8 gates. So, I’d like to dwell on this, if you can move over to page eight in your notes, here. Let me dwell on this for some time, and pontificate on a few things.

首先，正如我之前所说，这个数字很高，但并不是什么灾难。好吧，你不能在笔记本电脑上使用它，但对于台式机或服务器等来说，这是可以接受的。如果你把耳朵贴在台式电脑上，你总会听到它发出声音，而那个声音是由里面的一个大风扇发出的。

First of all, this number, as I said before, is high, but not a disaster. OK, so you can’t use this in laptops, but it’s quite OK for a desktop or a server, and so on. If you just go and put your ear to a pedestal computer, you’ll always hear it making a sound, and that sound is because of a big fan that’s inside it.

而且，如果你有一个足够大的风扇，250W 就不是什么大问题了。但是，对于移动设备来说，这肯定是一个真正的问题。对于笔记本电脑来说，这是不可想象的。好吧，我们必须解决这个问题。第二个问题是，1GHz 的功耗是 250W。现在，目前市场上能买到的最快的 Pentium 4 是多少 GHz？目前你能买到的最快的 Pentium 4 是多少？那是什么？

And, if you have a big enough fan, 250W is not such a big deal. But, this is certainly a real problem for mobile devices. For a laptop, this is unthinkable. OK, so we have to deal with this. The second issue is the following, that it’s 250W for 1GHz. Now, the fastest Pentium 4s that money can by today are, what, how many GHz? What’s the fastest Pentium 4 you can buy today? What’s that?

这里有人有 4GHz Pentium 4 吗？哦，该死，你打败我了。有人有 3.3GHz 的吗？有几台。所以，我有几台 3GHz 的机器，我们的实验室里有很多这样的机器。所以，如果英特尔今天推出 4GHz 的机器，那么在过去几年里，它们的速度大约每年都会提高 1GHz。

Does anybody have a 4GHz Pentium 4 here? Oh, darn, you beat me. Anybody have a 3.3GHz? A couple. So, I have a couple of 3GHz machines, and our lab has a whole ton of them. So, if Intel comes out with 4GHz machines today, they’ve been going up by about 1GHz roughly every year for the past couple of years.

而且，在三到四年内，你就会看到频率在 5 到 10GHz 范围内的芯片和微处理器，好吧，假设其他所有条件都保持不变，但当然情况并非如此，只是为了给你一些见解，如果我为这些家伙计时，并构建速度快十倍的电路，我很快就会达到 2.5kW，正如我所说的，其他所有条件都保持不变，但情况并非如此。

And, within three or four years, you’re going to see chips, microprocessors that are in the 5 10GHz range, OK, assuming that all other things stay equal, which of course they’re not, but just to give you some insight here, if I clock these guys and build circuits that are ten times faster, I very soon go up to 2.5kW, again as I said, all things being equal which they’re not.

但为了让你有个概念，当我增加频率时，芯片消耗的功率也会增加，对吧？所以，我真的必须在这里做点什么。所以，如果我盯着这个等式，CVS^2f，我想增加 f，因为如果我有更高的频率，人们就会购买电脑。而且，英特尔已经成功地利用其营销活动说服消费者，高频率是一件好事。

But just to give you a sense, as I increase my frequency, so does the power consumed by the chip, OK? So, I really have to do something here. So, if I stare at this equation, CVS^2f, I want to increase f because people will buy computers if I have higher frequencies. And, Intel has managed to use its marketing campaigns to pretty much convince consumers that high frequencies are a good thing.

好吧，不管它们是否真的有意义，那都是另一个问题。我们假设 5V 具有如此巨大的功率，好吧，事实证明，随着微处理器的推出，越来越新的版本在越来越低的电压下运行。好吧，他们发明了使用越来越低电压的技术，从 VS 5V 到今天的 VS 大约 1.5 到 1V，在这个范围内的某个地方。

OK, and whether they really mean anything or not, that’s a different issue. So, we’ve got this huge power for assuming 5V, OK, so it turns out that microprocessors, as they come out, newer and newer versions run at lower and lower voltages. OK, they invent technologies that use lower and lower voltages, and go from VS 5V to, today, VS on the order of 1.5 to 1V, somewhere in that range.

所以，一旦你这样做，功率就会减少 25 倍。好吧，从 2.5kW 开始，现在功率会降到 100W 左右，这又要合理得多，当然，前提是其他条件相同。事实证明，随着设备越来越小，设备的电容也会发生变化。而且，100W 也相当高，对于移动计算机来说还不够好。

So the moment you do that, you get a 25x reduction in power. OK, so in going from 2.5kW, you would now come down to something on the order of 100W, which is, again, much more reasonable, again, all other things being equal. It turns out that the capacitance of devices also changes as you go to smaller and smaller devices. And, 100W is also pretty high, and still not good enough for mobile computers.

因此，人们使用很多其他技巧来获得更低的功率。其中一个技巧是玩弄时钟。好的，您要做的就是，例如，在某些计算中，您不会使用浮点单元。或者，假设我将使用您的整数加法器单元。

So, there are many, many other tricks that people use to get even lower powers. One trick is to play games with the clock. OK, what you do is, let’s say for example in some computation you are not going to be using your floating point unit. Or let’s say I’m going to be using your integer adder unit.

好的，所以你可以关闭这些设备的时钟，这样这些设备在不工作时甚至不会切换。好的，如果我关闭某个设备的时钟，该设备甚至不会切换，它只是处于静止状态，不会消耗任何电量。这相当于关闭两个晶体管。

OK, so what you can do is you can turn off the clock to those devices so that those devices do not even switch when they’re not working. OK, if I turn off the clock to a device, the device isn’t even going to switch, it’s just going to sit there in limbo without consuming any power. It’s equivalent to turning off both transistors.

如果您以某种方式关闭 PMOS 和 NMOS，那么它就不会消耗任何功率。通过这样做，您可以进一步降低功率。因此，如果您可以让一些功能单元闲置，这称为让功能单元闲置，假设让功能单元闲置一半的时间。那么，您将再将功率降低两倍。我们可以让其闲置 75% 的时间，将功率降至 25W。

If you turn off both the PMOS and NMOS somehow, OK, it’s not consuming any power. And by doing that, you can further cut down the power. So, if you can idle some of your function units, it’s called idling a function unit, idle a function unit for, let’s say, half the time. OK, you would cut down power by another factor of two. We can idle, then, 75% of the time, come down to 25W.

所以，这些都是人们玩弄的把戏。我要在这里停下来，让地下向导们做调查。但是，可以说，我和你们讨论的关于电源的讨论是非常高水平的，关于真实情况的讨论。在现实生活中，实际上，即使对于 CMOS 逻辑，也存在相当多的待机功率。

So, those are the classes of tricks that people play. I’m going to stop here and allow the underground guide folks to do the survey. But, suffice it to say that the power discussion that I’ve gone through with you is a very high level discussion as to the real thing. In real life, what actually happens is that there is a fair amount of standby power even for CMOS logic.

事实证明，尽管我的两个晶体管没有从 VS 到地的路径，但还是存在许多漏电流。电流会通过逆变器的漏极等各种地方泄漏。因此，存在一些待机功率。所以，我先给大家展示一个快速演示，我想，此时，评论讲义正在分发。

It turns out that although I don’t have a path from VS to ground for my two transistors, it turns out that there are many leakage currents. OK, currents leak through all kinds of places through the drain of the inverter, and so on and so forth. And so, there is some standby power. So, let me show you a quick demo while, I guess, the review handouts are going around.

这显示了我的 CMOS 反相器的温度，随着我增加频率，您可以看到温度上升，希望我们会烧坏这个晶体管。所以，我正在增加频率，正如您在这边看到的，更高的频率意味着更多的功耗，更高的温度，好的，希望您会看到一些烟冒出来，好的，我想我烧坏了反相器。所以，输出消失了。

And this shows the temperature of my CMOS inverter, and as I increase the frequency, you can just watch the temperature go up, and hopefully we’ll blow this transistor. So, I’m increasing the frequency as you can see on the side here, and higher frequency implies more power consumption, more temperature, OK, and hopefully you will see some smoke coming out of, OK, I think I blew the inverter. So, the output is gone.

那里的温度是 110 华氏度，这太糟糕了。有时我们会看到烟雾冒出来，但我想今天不是我们的幸运日。好的，让我在这里停下来，让地下导游们浏览一下评论。

So, it’s at 110 degrees there, and that blew it. Sometimes we see smoke come out, but I guess today is not one of our lucky days. OK, so let me stop here and have the underground guide folks go through the reviews.

Lec 25 | MIT 6.002 电路与电子学，2007 年春季

Lec 25 | MIT 6.002 Circuits and Electronics, Spring 2007

17 年前 (2008 年 1 月 17 日) — 46:38 https://youtube.com/watch?v=dyxcCoUgETU

17 years ago (Jan 17, 2008) — 46:38 https://youtube.com/watch?v=dyxcCoUgETU

好的。早上好。早上好。那么，我们今天的讲座有一些有趣的东西，至于期末考试等等，我希望你们完全忘记我们今天所做的一切。所以，让你的大脑一片空白，忘记你在今天的讲座上听到的任何东西。所以，我今天要向你们展示的东西希望会让你们大吃一惊。我说的不是管制物质之类的东西。

All right. Good morning. Good morning. So, we have some fun stuff for today’s lecture, and as far as the final is concerned and so on, I’d like you to forget about anything we do today, absolutely. So, get your mind to become a blank, and forget anything you hear in today’s lecture. So, what I’m going to show you today will hopefully completely blow your minds. And I’m not talking about controlled substances or anything.

因此，我要向你们展示一些行为方式与你们预期截然不同的东西。今天的讲座恰如其分地被称为“OK”。因此，我们将在这里打破抽象障碍，做一些有趣的事情。

So what I’m going to do is show you a few things that behave completely and spectacularly differently than how you expect them to. And, today’s lecture is appropriately called OK. So, we’re going to violate the abstraction barrier here, and do some fun things.

重要的是要意识到，在 6.002 课程中，我们毕竟基于在课程开始时做出的一些假设，如集中物质学科等，将自己置于这个称为 6.002 的操场中。并且，在这个操场中，适用某些基本规则。好吧，我们的整个课程都依赖于这些假设是否正确。

And, the important thing to realize is that in all of 6.002, we have, after all, based on some assumptions we made at the beginning of the course like lumped matter discipline and so on, we have landed ourselves in this playground called the playground of 6.002. And, within that playground, certain ground rules apply. OK, and our entire course depended on those assumptions being true.

例如，我们从麦克斯韦方程组到集总物质学科的第一个假设是，或者更确切地说，电路抽象是集总物质学科。集总物质学科有三个原则。

So, for example, the first assumption we made that brought us from Maxwell’s equations to the lumped matter discipline was, or rather the circuit abstraction, was a lumped matter discipline. And there were three tenets of the lumped matter discipline.

一是电路中的通量变化率为零，不是在元件内部，而是在电路本身；二是 dq 乘以 dt 在元件外部为零；三是我们在课程中没有详细讨论，但课程笔记中肯定有提到，我们将要考虑的信号速度将比光速慢得多。

One is that the rate of change of flux was going to be zero within our circuits, not inside elements, but in the circuit itself, and second, the dq by dt was going to be zero outside the elements, and third, something we did not dwell upon in the course, but it’s certainly present in the course notes is that the speeds of signals that we are going to consider are going to be much slower than the speed of light.

好的，我们将在一个比光速慢得多的领域中工作。好的，从那开始，让我带您了解一些示例和一些有趣的东西。所以，第一个案例叫做 Double Take。所以，让我为您勾勒出一个小电路，看看预期的行为，然后向您展示现实生活中真正发生的事情。

OK, so we’re going to be working in a realm where we are going to be well slower than the speed of light. OK, so starting with that, let me walk you through some examples and some fun stuff. So, the first case is called the Double Take. So, let me sketch out a small little circuit for you, and take a look at the expected behavior, and then show you what really happens in real life.

第一种情况，我有一个电压源，我要做的是从零到一的转换。把它想象成一个阶跃输入，通过一个类似戴维南的电阻，我想把它送到一个电路。电路将进入一个逆变器。这个节点进入一个逆变器，并通过我们自己设计中的其他电路。

So, the first case, I have a voltage source, and what I’m going to do is make a transition from a zero to a one. Think of it as a step input, and through a Thevenin like resistance, I want to feed it to a circuit. The circuit will go to an inverter. This node goes to an inverter, and goes through some other circuits within our own design here.

所以，再次记住，这里有一个阶跃输入，这个输入会经过类似戴维南的电阻，或者施加到其他电路元件上。所以，如果我在这里应用一个阶跃，你会期待什么？你会期待，所以让我称之为 VI，让我称之为 Vo。

So, again, remember, a step input here, and this input goes through a Thevenin like resistance, or is applied to some other circuit elements. So, if I apply a step here, what do you expect? You expect that, so let me call that VI, and let me call that Vo.

因此，如果我将 VI 绘制为时间函数，假设此阶跃输入发生在 t=0 时。假设此处为 t=0，假设这是一个 5V 阶跃。因此，我预计此处的输入将在 t=0 时变为 VI，即 5V。我预计 Vo 会是什么情况？根据我们的电路抽象，在 Vo 时，我得到一个阶跃输入。

So, if I plot VI as a function of time, and let’s say this step input happens at t=0. So let’s say this is t=0 here, and let’s say this is a 5V step. So, I expect that this input here is going to go to, VI here, is going to go to 5V at t=0. What do I expect at Vo? At Vo, based on our circuit abstraction, I get a step input here.

我应该在这里得到一个幅度较大的步骤，这取决于在这个方向上连接了什么。我们简单地说，这里连接的是一个反相器，另一边可能还有其他反相器。所以本质上，就这个节点而言，它有一些电线与之相连。在电线的末端，它有一个开路，例如，像这个反相器的栅极输入一样的开路。

I should get a step of some magnitude here, depending on what’s connected in this direction. And let’s simply say that what’s connected here is an inverter, and maybe other inverters at the other side. So essentially, as far as this node is concerned, it’s got some wires connected to it. And at the end of the wires, it has an open circuit, an open circuit, for example, like the gate input of this inverter.

那么，在 V 为零时，您期望什么？这里是阶跃输入，在 V 为零时，我看到一个开路。好的，所以我期望在 V 为零时出现相同的阶跃：5V。所以，这就是我们为您准备的，好吗？但是，我们将要看到的有趣的东西，所以这是您所期望的，我将向您展示一个小演示，它将向您展示一些非常不同的东西。您将要看到的不是这个。

So what do you expect at V nought? A step input here, and at V nought I see an open circuit. OK, so I expect the same step at V nought: 5V. So, that’s what we’ve prepared you for, OK? But, the fun thing that we’re going to see, so this is what you expect, and I’ll show you a little demo that is going to show you something very different. What you’re going to see is not this.

好的，你不会看到这个。相反，我要给你看一些类似的东西。所以，在 t=0 时，我确实看到 Vo 看起来像一个台阶，大约在一半的时候，决定，啊，没关系，然后变平，好的，然后说，哦，好的，然后放大，它回到 5V。所以，它有点像双重反应，说，嘿，这里发生了什么？

OK, you’re not going to be seeing that. Rather, I’m going to show you something that looks like this. So, at t=0, I do see Vo looking like a step, and approximately halfway through, decides, ah, well never mind, and flattens out, OK, then says, oh, OK, and zoom, it goes back up to 5V. So, it sort of does a bit of a double take up there saying, hey, what’s going on here?

然后放大，跳到 5V，然后如您所料变成 5。好的，这是看起来像这样的有限时间。好的，尝试了解发生了什么。让我向您展示一个简短的小演示。这就是输入 VI。好的，这就是您期望的输入 VI，此时我不会对我的电路做任何事情。然后，继续。那么，让我们看看现在会发生什么。

And zoom, jumps up to 5V, and then it’s five as you expect. OK, so this is some finite amount of time that looks like that. OK, so try to understand what’s going on. So let me show you a quick little demo. So that’s the input VI. OK, so that’s the input VI that you expect, and I won’t do anything to my circuit at this point. And, go ahead. So, let’s see what happens now.

好了。现在，我向你展示 Vo 的输出。在 VI 处，有一个不错的小步骤，在 Vo 处，请注意，我得到了类似这样的结果。好的，我向你保证，我们在 6.002 中教给你的任何东西都无法让你为此做好准备。好的，正如我在本讲座开始时提到的，你应该在接下来的至少两周内忘记你在今天的讲座中学到的一切。

There you go. So now, I’m showing you the output here at Vo. So at VI, there’s a nice little step, and at Vo, notice that I get something that behaves like this. OK, and I promise you, nothing we’ve taught you in 6.002 prepares you for this. OK, and as I mentioned at the beginning of this lecture, it would behoove you to forget about everything you learn in today’s lecture for the next two weeks at least.

那么这里发生了什么？有什么想法吗？有人吗？有什么想法吗？那么我的电路怎么了？它说，哦，好的，一步。它开始说，哦，没关系，然后在 2.5V 处蜿蜒前行，然后说，哦，一步，是的，我记得，然后砰的一声，它跳到了 5V。那么，有什么理论吗？有什么猜测吗？有什么大胆的猜测吗？

So what’s going on here? Any ideas? Anybody? Any thoughts? So what’s up with my circuit here? It says, oh, OK, a step. It starts off and says, oh, never mind, and then meanders along at 2.5V and then says oh, step, yes, I remember, and then boom, it jumps up to 5V. So, any theories? Any guesses? Any wild guesses?

好的，让我给你画一个更详细的电路，看看你能否解释一下这里发生了什么。所以，我画的电路与我手上的电路不太一样，至少在电线方面是这样。所以我有这样的东西，VI，它将步进到 5V。我确实有一个电阻，R。这是 Vo，它确实会进入逆变器。

OK, so let me draw you a little bit more of a detailed circuit, and see if you can explain what’s going on here. So, the circuit that I’ve drawn there is not quite the circuit I have at least in terms of my wires. So, what I have is something that looks like this, VI, and this is going to step to 5V. I do have a resistance, R. This is Vo, this does go to an inverter.

但同时发生的事情是，我有一根很长的电线。好吧，你看到这家伙了吗？我们让一名工会成员沿着这里的地板伸展开来。我们有一根很长的电线连接到 Vo 节点，还有一条很长的对应地线。所以，这根电线是用于以太网等的同轴电缆。

But what is also happening is that I have a long wire. OK, you see this guy here? We had one of our union folks stretch out along the floor here. We have a really long wire that connects to the Vo node, and there’s also a long corresponding ground. So, this wire is a coaxial cable that is used for Ethernet and such like.

它有一个传输信号的芯线，芯线周围是屏蔽层，也就是地线。好的，这样走了很长一段路，最后是开路。好的，最后是开路。我还没有连接任何东西：开路。所以，你知道，这里发生了一些事情，导致电路像这样运行。所以，这是 VI。在 Vo 所以在 Vo 时，我得到了这种奇怪的行为。

It’s got a core that carries a signal, and around the core is shielding that is the ground. OK, so that goes a long way, and at the end, it is open. OK, it’s an open circuit at the end. I haven’t connected anything out there: open circuit. So, you know, something’s happening here that’s making the circuit behave like this. So, this is VI. At Vo So at Vo I’m getting this funny behavior.

好的，那么有人想在这里找到下一个线索吗？有人想猜猜这里会发生什么吗？是吗？啊，我们的观众中有一个托儿。所以，理论上，这里的步骤，可以想象成从零到五的电磁脉冲，而现实生活中的东西不会瞬间移动。

OK, so does anybody want to take the next piece of clues here, does anybody want to take a stab at guessing what might be going on here? Yes? Ah, we have a shill in the audience here. So, the theory is that the step here, think of it as an electromagnetic pulse that goes from zero to five, and things in real life don’t travel instantaneously.

所以，有一种波向下飞，波到末端，翻转，然后回来，然后在这里建立全电压。所以这确实是发生情况的根源。让我用外行人能理解的语言来解释，然后描述这里发生的情况的细节。好的，所以查看发生情况的方式是我有这根长电线。

So, there’s something with a wave that flies down, and the wave goes to the end, flips, and then comes back, and then establishes the full voltage here. So that is indeed at the root of what’s going on. And let me put it in layman’s terms and then describe the details of what’s going on here. OK, so the way to view what’s going on is that I have this long wire.

好的，在第一堂课中，我一开始就说电线是理想的。好的，理想的电线是这样的，我可以在它们上面传输信号。电线很小，因此信号的传播时间与目标信号的上升时间和下降时间相比微不足道。通过在这里使用这根非常长的电缆，我显然违反了这一假设，即这里的电线非常非常长。

OK, in the very first lecture, I started off by saying wires are ideal. OK, ideal wires are such that I can transmit signals on them. Wires are small so that the propagation time of signals is inconsequential compared to the rise times and fall times of the signals of interest. By having this really long cable here, I have clearly violated that assumption, which is the wires are really, really long here.

好的，所以我需要以某种方式模拟在没有小电线的情况下电线对我的电路的作用。那么实际发生的情况，观察它的方式如下。所以，虽然这是一根电线，但为了理解正在发生的事情的机制，我真的必须更准确地模拟它，好吗？

OK, and so I somehow need to model what the wire is doing to my circuit when I don’t have a small wire. So what actually happens, the way to view it is the following. So, although this is a wire, to understand the mechanics of what’s going on, I really have to model it much more accurately, OK?

而对这种电线进行建模的方法是，注意电线的每个小元件都与某种电感相关。好的，让我们取一小段同轴电缆。同轴电缆是被金属屏蔽层包围的小芯线。好的，那是地线。因此，当我有一根被金属屏蔽层包围的电线时，它也具有电容，好的，电感和电容。

And, the way to model a wire like this is that notice that every small element of a wire has associated with it some inductance. OK, so let’s take a small segment of the coax cable here. The coax cable is a small core surrounded by a metallic shield. OK, that’s a ground. And so, when I have a wire surrounded by a metallic shield, that also has the capacitance, OK, inductance and capacitance.

因此，这一小段可以建模为一个非常小的电感和一个非常小的电容。同样，下一段可以建模为一个微小的电感和一个电容。这里也有一个电阻，但我们假设我们的模型中的电阻为零，并且并联电阻也是无穷大。

So this small segment can be modeled as a really small inductance, and a really tiny capacitance. Similarly, the next segment can be modeled as a tiny inductance and a capacitance. There is also a resistance here, but let’s assume that the resistance is zero for our model, and also the parallel resistance is also infinity.

好的，所以它是一个电感器、电容器，而我遇到的情况实际上不是一对理想的导线，而是一个非常非常小的电感和并联的小电容。所以，我这里遇到的更像是一组分布式元件。请注意，在我的集中电路抽象中，当我们讨论两个逆变器之间的导线的 RLC 模型时，我们将其集中起来。

OK, so it’s an inductor, capacitor, and really the situation that I have is not a pair of ideal wires, but really a really, really small inductance, and a small capacitance in parallel. So, it’s more of a set of distributed elements that I have here. Notice that in my lump circuit abstraction, when we talked about the RLC model for the wire between two inverters, we lumped it.

我们将这个东西集中到一个看起来像这样的模型中。好的，我们将电阻集中到一个源电阻中。我们将所有电感器集中到一个集中电感器中。我们将所有电容集中到一个集中电容中。好的，但在这种情况下，当感兴趣的信号速度比光速慢得多，比电磁信号的传播速度慢得多时，我可以这样做。在这种情况下，这并不完全正确。

We lumped this thing into a model that looked like this. OK, we lumped the resistance into a source resistance. We lumped all the inductors into a lumped inductor. We lumped all the capacitances into a lumped capacitance. OK, but in this situation, I can do this when the signal speeds of interest are much, much, much slower than the speed of light than the propagation speeds of electromagnetic signals. In this case, that is not quite true.

因此，我们必须更精确地对其进行建模。我们需要了解发生了什么。所以，这里发生的事情是，在 t=0 时，我得到了这一步。所以，把它想象成一个能量脉冲，它到达这里的瞬间，瞬间这个家伙看起来像一个分压器，好吗？我在这里选择了电阻 ​​R，以匹配瞬时阻抗，也就是 R。我已经将它安排成那样了。

And so, therefore, we have to model it much more exactly. We need to see what’s going on. So, what’s happening here is that at t=0, I get this step. So, think of that as a pulse of energy, and the instant it comes here, and instantaneously this guy looks like a voltage divider, OK? I’ve chosen my resistance, R, here to match the instantaneous impedance looking in, which is also R. I’ve arranged it to be that way.

因此，瞬时，脉冲出现的点，从这里往下看，看起来像是这个脉冲的另一个电阻。好的，因此，当我开始时，我开始上升并在 2.5 处暂停，因为瞬时，这看起来像一个电阻，R。所以瞬时，它是一个分压器，R，所以这里瞬时是 2.5。好的，然后会发生什么？然后那些小脉冲向下传播。

So, instantaneously, the point at which the pulse appears at this point, looking down here looks like another resistor to this pulse. OK, therefore, when I start out, I start out going up and pausing at 2.5 because instantaneously, this looks like a resistance, R. So instantaneously, it’s a voltage divider, R, and so it’s 2.5 here, instantaneously. OK, then what happens? Then those little pulse propagates down.

能量脉冲向下传播意味着什么？嗯，它开始通过电感器发送电流，开始给电容器充电，电流在这里，这就是我说能量脉冲向下传播的意思。好吧，这是一个步骤，它将电流发送到电感器并为电容器充电，波前从这里移出并一直到这里。那里发生了什么？好吧，想想看。

What does it mean for a pulse of energy to propagate down? Well, it begins sending a current through the inductor, begins charging up the capacitor, current here, so that’s what I mean by saying that the pulse of energy goes down. OK, it’s a step that sends current to the inductor and charges of the capacitors, and that wave front moves out here and comes all the way here. What happens there? Well, think about it.

假设你站在这里，手里拿着一根长绳，然后做这个思想实验。这并不容易。所以，假设你手里拿着一根长绳，绳子另一边没有连接任何东西。好吧，想象一下这个实验。好吧，你要做的是突然把绳子从你那一端抬起大约一英尺。

Supposing you stand here, and you hold a long string in your hand somehow, and just do this Gedanken experiment. It’s not easy to do. And so, let’s say you somehow have the long string that you’re holding onto, and the string on the other side is not connected to anything. OK, just imagine this experiment. OK, and what you do is you suddenly raise the string up at your end by about a foot.

你会看到什么？瞬间，绳子在这里，但绳子的其余部分在下面一英尺处。然后你看到这个波沿着绳子向下传播，对吧？这是一根绳子。我把它举起来，你会看到这个波一直向下传播，一英尺的波一直向下传播，直到你来到这里。这里发生了什么？

What are you going to see happen? So instantaneously, the string is up here, but the rest of the string is down a foot below. And then you see this wave propagate down the string, right? So here’s a string. I lift this thing, and you see this wave propagate all the way down, the one foot wave propagate all the way down until you come here. What happens here?

所以，在这里，绳子在这里，波从这里传播，把它拉到 1。然后呢？那里没有连接任何东西，所以绳子被拉紧了，但它有能量。好的，能量去哪里了？嗯，它继续向上，并发出波回来。好的，想象一下你像这样拉起一根绳子，然后向下传播，砰，击中另一端，反转，然后回到我身边。

So, out here, the string is down here, the wave propagates out here and pulls it up to one. And then what? There’s nothing connected there, so the string is zipped up, but it’s got the energy. OK, where does energy go? Well, it continues going up, and sends a wave back. OK, so just think of a string that you pull up like this and propagates down, boom, hits the other end, reverses, and comes back at me.

好的，您可以看一个互补的情况，与此不同，但通过将绳子绑在门上并将其抬起来，可以实现互补。这不是同一种情况。这是一种绑住绳子的互补情况。绑住绳子相当于在此处将两端短路。

OK, you can look at a complementary situation, not the same as this, but complementary by taking a string, tying it to a door, and lifting it up. It’s not the same situation. It’s a complementary situation where it’s tied down. Tying down a string is tantamount to shorting the ends here.

好的，在这种情况下，你会看到这样的情况：当波浪向下时，绳子末端无法移动，所以波浪会去掉头并翻转回来。在家试试吧。拿一根长绳子，把它绑在那里，这样做，好吗？你会看到波浪去掉头，翻转，然后回到你身边。

OK, in that case what you’ll see happen: as the wave goes down, at the end the string can’t move, so the wave goes and flips around and comes back. Try it out at home. Take a long piece of string, tie it up there, do this, OK? And you’ll see the wave go out, flip, and then come back at you.

所以，如果你的朋友看到​​你用一根长绳子做这个动作，希望他们不会认为你疯了。好的，这里也是一样：这个东西飞下来，好的，这里没有办法消散能量，所以这个东西继续向上。然后，我将看到波向后移动。好的，波开始向后移动，这是另一个 2.5V，导致此端子的净电压为 5V。

So, if your friends see you tying a long piece of string doing this, hopefully they won’t think you’re nuts or something. OK, so the same way here: this thing flies down, OK, there’s no way to dissipate the energy here, so this thing continues up. And then, what I’m going to see happen is the wave move back. OK, the wave begins to move back, and that’s another 2.5V, resulting in a net 5V at this terminal.

波开始反弹，好吧，然后当它回到这里时，经过一段时间后，它会升至 5V，这就是您在这里看到的。所以，这是一个下降的波，然后经过 2t 的时间后，它会回到 5V。这是一个返回波。它是 2t，因为下降到这里需要 t 秒，然后返回需要 t 秒，这就是为什么我们有 2t。

That wave begins to blast back, OK, and then when it comes back here, after some amount of time, it raises this to 5V, and that’s what you see happen here. So, this is a wave going down, and then after a time, 2t, it goes back up to 5V. That’s a return wave. It’s 2t because to get down here is t seconds, and then t seconds to come back, which is why we have 2t.

好的，这就是你在 2.5 处看到那个脉冲的原因。好的，我想在这里向你展示更多东西。显然，我们不希望在我们的电路中出现这种情况。有人能告诉我，如果我的数字电路中的信号看起来像这样，会发生什么问题吗？如果中间有一个小东西，然后是一个台阶，而不是漂亮的小台阶，这样的信号有什么问题？

OK, that is why you see that pulse at 2.5. OK, so I’d like to show you a few more things here. Clearly we don’t want that in our circuits. Could someone tell me what problem would happen if my signals looked like this in my digital circuits? Instead of being nice little steps, if there was a little thing in the middle and then a step, what’s the problem with signals like this?

在数字电路中，它违反了什么？是吗？没错。这个小家伙在 2T 的禁区内徘徊。不能这样做。好的，不能这样做。好吧，所以我们需要解决这个问题，因为这是现实生活。好的，但是如果你和你的伙伴在互相发送信号，但使用数字信号从一个宿舍传到另一个宿舍，可能几百英尺深，会怎么样？

In digital circuits, what did it violate? Yeah? Exactly. This little sucker here is meandering out in the forbidden region for all of 2T. Can’t do that. OK, can’t have that. Well, so we need to fix the problem because this is real life. OK, but what if you and your buddy were signaling each other but using digital signals from one dorm room to another maybe a few hundred feet down?

你的电路无法工作，因为信号会在禁区内徘徊一段时间。那么，有什么想法可以做吗？是吗？在末端放一个电阻。好的，对电路进行一些改动。那么，你可以做什么，我将在这里向你展示一个小演示，你可以做的是，我让这个波传播回来的原因是没有任何东西可以吸收能量。

Your circuit isn’t going to work because the signal’s going to meander around in the forbidden region for some time. So, any ideas what might you do? Yeah? Put a resistor on the end. OK, trick the circuit. So, what you can do, and I’m going to show you a little demo here, what you can do is the reason I got this wave propagating back, was that there was nothing to absorb the energy.

那么，如果我在这里放置另一个电阻器 R，情况会怎样？就能量爆发而言，它说，哦，是的，它看起来是一样的。它是 R，然后消散在这个电阻器 R 中，你猜怎么着？我没有任何波返回，我完成了。

So instead, what if I put another resistor here, R? So, as far as a burst of energy is concerned, it says, oh, yeah, it just looks the same. It’s R, and goes and dissipates in this resistor, R, and guess what? I don’t have any wave going back, and I’m done.

那么，我要找到的是，在这里，这个电压上升到 5V，但在这里，我将得到一个信号，一开始上升到 2.5，就是这样。好的，我将其提升，它下降，它下降到 2.5，因为在您处理的集总模型中，它是一个电阻器 R，一个接地电阻器 R，您将在这里或这里进行连接。

So, what I’m going to find, then, is that out here, this goes up to 5V, but out here, I will have a signal that starts out and goes up to 2.5, and that’s it. OK, I lift it up, it goes down, it goes to 2.5 because in the lumped model that you’ve been dealing with, it’s a resistor R, a resistor R to ground, and you’re taking the connection here or here.

所以，这是你的标准集总模型，你的电压电阻分压器，它只是简单地工作。是的，就是这样。所以，这是电缆的末端。好的，如果你能以某种方式同时看到这个和那个，那么我要做的是，这是一个电阻器，R，我要把它插上。好的，如果命运对我微笑，你应该在那里看到什么？

So, it’s your standard lumped model, your voltage resistive divider, and it just simply works. Yeah, that’s it. So, this is the end of the cable. OK, if somehow you could watch this and that at the same time, so what I’m going to do, and this is a resistor, R, I’m just going to plug it in. OK, if the fates are smiling at me, what should you see there?

应该发生的是，从 2.5 到 5 的第二次跳跃应该会消失。它应该直接跳到 2.5。让我们试试看。就是这样。我把它拿出来，它又跳回来了。好的，所以我在这里所做的就是在末端放一个电阻器，我仍然在这里测量电压。所以，这是一个解决方案。一个解决方案是在这里放一个电阻器。

What should happen is that the second jump from 2.5 to 5 should simply go away. It should just go to 2.5. Let’s try that. There you go. I take it out, it jumps back up. OK, so all I’ve done here is put in a resistor at the end, and I’m still measuring the voltage here. So, that’s one solution. One solution is to put a resistor here.

因此，我吸收能量，电阻必须等于瞬时阻抗。对于许多电缆来说，瞬时阻抗为 50 欧姆。这被称为特性阻抗。好的，如果你学习 6.014，你会学到更多关于它的知识。该课程首先假设事物在物质中是分布的。

So, I absorb the energy, and the resistance has to be equal to the instantaneous impedance looking in. And the instantaneous impedance, for many of these cables is 50 ohms. It’s called a characteristic impedance. OK, you’ll learn a lot more about it if you take 6.014. That course starts out with assuming that things are distributed in that matter.

好吧，如果你想设计几千兆赫的芯片，那么事实证明，如果你的信号以 0.1 1 纳秒范围内的边缘速度传播，请记住，光传播的速度大约是每英尺一纳秒。如果感兴趣的信号大致为 0.1 纳秒，那么如果芯片尺寸为一英寸，那么信号在芯片上的传播速度就是 0.1 纳秒。

OK, so if you want to design multi gigahertz chips, it turns out that if you have signals that are traveling around at edge speeds in the 0.1 1 nanosecond range, remember, light travels roughly one nanosecond a foot. And if the signals are roughly of interest are 0.1 nanoseconds, then if the chips are one inch in size, right there, the propagation speed of a signal across a chip is 0.1 nanoseconds.

好的，今天，我们必须处理这些问题，并设法找出解决它们的方法。好的，这是有人指出的一个解决方案。还有第二个解决方案。还有人有第二个解决方案给我吗？还有第三个解决方案。所以没关系。你可以给我第二个或第三个解决方案。没关系。有人吗？你有两个可供选择，来吧。是吗？

是的，你可以这样做。所以我们可以通过说这种转变使得我的高点低于 2.5 来定义问题。所以，一旦它超过 2.5，谁在乎它会发生什么？这是一个很好的观点。这是解决方案四，而且有效。好的，所以我仍然需要二和三。在那里放一个二极管？是的，我想你可以。

如果二极管具有相同类型的阻抗，它可能会起作用。这是解决方案 4.2。我还在等待解决方案二和三。什么？切断电缆？没错。所以，解决方案说，解决另一个问题。这是解决方案二。好的，所以这个想法是，万恶之源是这根长电线，这就是我在这里放这个东西的原因。

因此，如果我有短线，那么如果线很细，就会出现这种情况，它看起来会像这样。而且线足够小。我会看到一个很小的东西，但不会很多。顺便说一句，有趣的是，你实际上可以计算光速，这是我刚刚向你展示的实验。我们可以再举一个例子吗？不，是那个大东西。

So instead, if I had short wires, then what will happen is if it’s a very small wire, it’ll look like this. And the wire’s small enough. 所以，在我向你们展示的实验中，这个距离大约是 500 纳秒，对吧？这个距离是这个时间间隔的 500 纳秒。这根电缆的长度大约是 500 英尺，大约 500 英尺。所以你可以算出光速。光速是多少？所以，这大约是 500 纳秒，这根电缆大约是 500 英尺。光速是多少？大约是每纳秒一英尺。

So, in the experiment that I showed you, this distance was about 500 nanoseconds, OK? This distance was 500 nanoseconds this time interval. The length of this cable is about 500 feet, somewhere around 500 feet. So you can figure out the speed of light. What’s the speed of light? So, this is about 500 nanoseconds, and this cable is roughly 500 feet. What’s the speed of light? Roughly a foot per nanosecond.

那么，你会相信在 6.002 中我们通过一个简单的实验算出了光速吗？好的，现在让我们做下一个实验。我们把长电缆取出来，然后连接一条短电缆。我要做的是断开长电缆，然后连接一条小电缆。它仍然相对较长，但比 500 英尺长的电缆短得多。

So, would you believe that in 6.002 we’ve figured out the speed of light from a simple experiment? All right, so let’s do the next experiment now. Let’s take out the long cable, and connect a short cable instead. So, what I’m going to do is disconnect the long cable, and instead, connect a small cable. It’s still relatively long, but much shorter than the 500 foot cable.

所以现在你应该看到，小步不应该这么大，而应该小得多。所以，看看那里。就是这样。好的，有了这个东西，那里的小点非常小。当然，如果我把它做得更小，那么它几乎可以消失。好的，这是第二个解决方案。所以，我们已经完成了一、二、四、4.2。那么，第三个解决方案是什么？还有一个解决方案。什么？

So what you should see happen now is that the little step should not be this big, but much, much smaller. So, take a look up there. There you go. 因此，我们提到的另一个解决方案是改变这个电阻。这样会起作用，如果我把这个电阻调得很低，那么我就会更接近 5V。是的，这是有可能的。我想这是解决方案六。那么解决方案三是什么？你们都应该能够解决这个问题。你们知道答案。好的，你们应该能够解决这个问题。是吗？啊，时钟。

So, another solution we mentioned is we change this resistance. and that will work, if I make this very, very low, then I’ll get much closer to 5V here. Yeah, that’s a possibility. That’s solution six I guess. So what was solution number three? And you all should be able to solve this. You guys know the answer. OK, you folks should be able to solve this. Yes? Ah, clock.

因此，正如所指出的那样，我可以做的是，通过更改 VOH 和 VIH 阈值来利用我的抽象。这样就可以了。另一种方法是使用时钟。时钟是我在数字电路中发送的一个特殊信号，好吗？

So, what I can do is just as was pointed out, that I leveraged my abstraction by changing my VOH and VIH thresholds. So that’ll work. The alternative thing is to use a clock. A clock is a distinguished signal that I send around in my digital circuit, OK?

因此，我所做的就是，如果我安排时钟不在这个附近发生，而是让我的时钟发生得足够晚，那么我将只在时钟的上升沿和下降沿采样并查看信号，在这种情况下，我不会查看信号，但信号会做奇怪的事情。好的，所以一个合适的时钟也可以解决这个问题。

So all I do is if I arrange it such that my clock doesn’t happen in this vicinity, but rather, my clock happens late enough, then I’m going to sample and look at my signals only on the rising and falling edges of the clock, in which case I won’t be looking at the signal, but the signal is doing weird things. OK, so a decent clock would also solve the problem.

好的，在我们进入下一个问题之前，还有什么问题吗？好的，我们要研究的下一个问题叫做 Double Dip。好的，我在这里要做的是 Vs 电源，我要做的是将电源馈送到逆变器。好的，我们一直在这样做；Vs，我将电源馈送到逆变器。

OK, any last minute questions before we go onto the next one? OK, the next problem that we’re going to look at is titled the Double Dip. OK, so what I’m going to do here is our Vs power supply, and what I’m going to do is feed the power supply to an inverter. OK, so we’ve been doing this all along; Vs, I feed the supply to an inverter.

我还要做的是，这是地线，我要将它馈送到电源连接，馈送到几个逆变器。好的，我要做的是将某种信号施加到这个逆变器，然后我要观察，我要查看这里的信号。所以，抽象应该告诉你这是一个电源。

And what I’m also going to do is, so this is ground, and I’m going to feed it to, so feed the power supply connection to a couple of inverters. OK, and what I’m going to do is apply some sort of a signal to this inverter, and I’m going to observe, and I’m going to look at this signal here. So, the abstraction should tell you that here’s a power supply.

这是 5V，或者这两个逆变器的电源电压。这样应该没问题，然后向这个逆变器输入某种输入，好的，这里的输出应该由这个输入决定。这个信号绝对不会对这个输出产生影响。好的，让我们看看并确认一下。

This is 5V, or whatever the supply voltage is to these two inverters. That should be fine, and feed some sort of input to this inverter, OK, and the output here should be simply determined by this input. This signal can have absolutely no bearing on this output. OK, and let’s look at that and actually confirm it.

所以，我构建了一个这样的电路，我们看看这个输出，最初应该没有任何输出，它应该可以正常工作。好的，所以它现在应该可以工作了，对吧？好的。所以你在这里看到的，这个输入是我馈送到这个逆变器的输入。那是一条直线。那是电源吗？没关系？

So, I build a circuit like this, and we look at this output, and initially there should not be any, it should simply work fine. OK, so it should work now, right? OK. So what you have here, this input here is the input that I’m feeding to this inverter. That is a straight line. Is that the power supply? It doesn’t matter?

好的，我相信这是，我们过几分钟再检查一下，但我怀疑这是电源，这家伙是输出。所以，绿色的是看这里的部分。所以，这里一定有一个从 1 到 0 的转换，一切都很好。所以，到目前为止一切都很好。好的，到目前为止没有问题。

OK, so I believe this is the, we’ll check in a few minutes, but I suspect this is the power supply, and this guy here is the output looking here. So, the green one is the look here part. So, there must have been a one to zero transition here, and that’s all fine. So, so far, so good. OK, no problem so far.

现在我要对电路做一些事情，就抽象而言，它不会出现在电路上。好的，它在抽象层之下。好的，我要做一些事情，突然间，一些事情会发生。看那里。电路没有改变。它是同一个电路。我没有对电路做任何事情。好的，看看绿色输出。

Now what I’m going to do is I’m going to do something to the circuit that as far as abstraction is concerned, it doesn’t show up on the circuit. OK, it’s below the abstraction layer. OK, I’m going to do something, and suddenly, some things are going to happen. Look up there. The circuit hasn’t changed. It’s the same circuit. I’ve done nothing to the circuit. OK, look at the green output.

我没有对这里可见的电路做任何改动。好的，它在这里的雷达屏幕下面。它低于抽象屏障。但是，看看这里的灾难。好的，特别是，上升的尖峰不是什么大问题。由于静态约束，如果我处于五、六或七，只要我高于 VOH，就没关系。

I’ve done nothing to the circuit that is visible here. OK, it’s below the radar screen here. It’s below the abstraction barrier. But, look at the disaster here. OK, in particular, the spikes going up are not so much of a problem. Because of the static discipline, if I am at five or six or seven, it doesn’t matter as long as I am higher than VOH.

所以只要高于 VOH，就不会有问题。但问题是这些反复的下降。好吧，这里的下降是个问题，这就是我将这个实验称为双重下降的原因。好吧，下降很糟糕，因为如果它们足够大，它们就会将输出分组到禁区，或者更糟的是，让它看起来像零。好吧，所以你对此没有做好准备。

So as long as I’m higher than VOH I don’t have a problem. But the problems are these repeated dips. OK, the dips are a problem here, which is why I labeled this experiment the Double Dip. OK, the dips are bad because if they are large enough, they can then group the output down into the forbidden region, or worse yet, make it look like a zero. OK, so you’re not prepared for this.

我要做的是告诉你们我对电路做了什么，然后请你们帮我弄清楚。我所做的就是给它施加一个负载电阻，我想是 50 欧姆或一些 RL。我只是施加了一个负载电阻。我相信这里的这个反相器是一个 CMOS 反相器，看起来，好吗？

So what I’m going to do is tell you what I did to the circuit, and then ask you to help me figure it out. So all I did was applied a load resistance to this, I think of 50 ohms or some RL. I just applied a load resistor. And this inverter here, I believe, is a CMOS inverter that looks, OK?

所以我把这个输入应用到这个逆变器上，我所做的就是在这里应用一个 RL 负载。请注意，如果这是一个理想的逆变器，这里的负载不应该真正改变正在发生的事情，好的，这里的负载应该只是吸收一些电流，但实际上不应该改变任何其他属性。好的，所以只要记住，信号在做什么？信号很高。这个家伙打开了，电流像这样流动。

So I have this input applied to this inverter, and all I did is I applied an RL load here. And notice that the load here should not really change what’s happening if this is an ideal inverter, OK, the load here should simply draw some current but really should not change any other property. OK, so just remember, what’s the signal doing? The signal is high. This guy turns on, and current flows like this.

假设我这里有一个电容器。它像这样充电，当它慢速充电时，PFET 导通，电流从这里流到下面。然后当它变高时，这个电容器关闭，这个电容器打开。好的，所以电流以这种方式流出，这个电容器通过这个电容器充电。当我关闭它时，P 品位打开并从顶部汲取电流。

So, let’s say I had some sort of a capacitor here. This charges like this, and when it’s slow, the PFET is on, and current flows through here down here. And then when this goes high, this guy goes off, and this guy turns on. OK, so the current flows out this way and this charges through this guy. When I turn it off, the P fret turns on and draws current from the top.

好的，那么我们有什么理论可以解释为什么我会在逆变器的输出端看到那些乱七八糟的东西，即电压骤降和峰值？那么为什么逆变器会关心它的负载是多少呢？我的意思是，谁会在乎呢？所以，请开动你的思维。有什么理论吗？你们在前一个问题上做得很好。实际上，这个要容易得多。

OK, so do we have any theories as to why I’m getting that messy stuff, the dips and the spikes, on the output of this inverter? So why does this inverter care what the load of this inverter is? I mean, who cares? So, put your thinking caps on. Any theories? You guys did pretty well with the previous one. And this is much easier, actually.

需要更好的电源；好的，我要做的是更换电源，改用更大的 5V 电源。一个可以提供 100 安培的大型 Mongo 电源，你猜怎么着，我做了更改，但你猜怎么着，我仍然看到尖峰。不错的尝试，但没有成功。不错的尝试，不错的尝试。下一步是什么？还有其他解决方案吗？是吗？

Need a better power supply; OK, so what I’m going to do is I’m going to replace the power supply, and instead, use a much bigger power supply at 5V. A big, mongo power supply that can supply 100 amps, and guess what, I’ve made the changes, but guess what, I still see the spikes. Good try, but it didn’t work out. Good try, good try. What next? Any other solutions? Yes?

所以，下降是由于电阻引起的，而尖峰是由于电感引起的？你只对了一半。那么，到底是哪一个呢？所以，下降是由于电阻引起的，而尖峰是由于电感引起的。你只对了一半。事实证明，下降和尖峰都是由于电感引起的。好的，但无论如何，让我在这里给你下一个线索，然后看看你是否能更接近答案。

So dips are because of the resistance, and the spikes are because of the inductance? You’re half correct. So, which one is it? So, dips are because of resistances, and spikes are because of inductances. You’re half correct. It turns out that both the dips and the spikes are because of inductances. OK, but be that as it may, let me give you the next clue here, and then see if you can come closer to the answer.

我在这里做的是把这根电线做得非常非常长。好吧，这是一根非常长的电线，好吧，但它是一根粗电线，所以它是一根很长很粗的电线。所以这不是电阻。它非常非常粗，而且是一根很长的电线，所以接地平面上方的信号线就像一个电感器。所以这里，它有电容，但在这种情况下它是电感。这里是电感。

So, what I’ve done here is I’ve made this wire really, really long. OK, it’s a really long wire, OK, but it’s a thick wire, so it’s a long, long, thick wire. So it’s not the resistance. It’s really, really thick and mongo, and it’s a long wire, so a signal wire above a ground plane behaves like an inductor. And so here, it has the capacitance to, but in this case it’s inductance. It’s inductance here.

所以，我再给你十秒钟时间思考，然后告诉你答案。但尽管这里有电感，但事实证明，如果我取出这个电阻，问题就消失了。你看，我取出电阻，问题就消失了。是的，这里有一个电感。好的，我取出这个电阻，问题就消失了。我把电阻放回去，砰。是吗？好的，很好。这是 86 分。所以这就是发生的事情。

So, I’ll give you another ten seconds to think about it and then tell you the answer. But despite the inductance here, it turns out if I take out this resistor, the problem goes away. Look, I take out the resistor, the problem goes away. Yes, there is an inductor here. OK, I take out this resistor, problem goes away. I put the resistor back in, boom. Yes? OK, pretty good. That’s 86 points. So here’s what’s going on.

这里有一个电感器，当我在这里放置一个 50 欧姆电阻时，我放置了这个电阻器。当 PFET 导通时，它会吸收电流。好的，它会吸收电流。它会吸收电流；请记住，在电感器上有一个压降。压降与 di/dt 有关。请记住，对于电容器，电流为 Cdv/dt。对于电感器，电感器两端的电压为 Ldi/dt。

There’s an inductor here, and when I put a 50 ohm resistor here, I put this resistor. When the PFET turns on, it draws a current. OK, it’s going to draw a current. It draws a current; remember that across an inductor, I have a drop. And the drop relates to the di/dt. Remember, for a capacitor, the current is Cdv/dt. For the inductor, the voltage across the inductor is Ldi/dt.

因此，如果 di/dt 是每个周期通过电感切换大电流，好的，大 di/dt，di/dt 很大。我通过非常小的 RL 将其放大，因此，你知道，每隔几个周期，无论多少，每个周期都会拉一个大电流，然后停止它。因此，我得到了与 Ldi/dt 相关的电感上的大压降。换句话说，这里的电源没问题。

So, if di/dt, from switching a large current through the inductor every cycle, OK, big di/dt, di/dt is large. I’ve made it large by having a very small RL, so, you know, pulling a big current through every few, whatever, every cycle, and then stopping it. And so therefore, I’m getting these big drops across this inductor that relate to Ldi/dt. In other words, the power supply here is fine.

在你们观看的时候，我切换到了巨大的 mongo 电源，所以这个电压没问题。但是电线后面的电压就是问题所在。所以，这里的电压看起来不再像这样了。相反，它有尖峰，例如，它会下降，而当我切换到另一个方向时，它们会上升。好的，因此，我最终得到的是这个电源上的大尖峰。

While you guys were watching, I switched to the huge, mongo power supply, and so this voltage is fine. But then this voltage after the wire is the problem. So, this voltage here doesn’t look like this anymore. Rather, it has spikes that go down, for example, and when I switch the other way, they go up. OK, so therefore, what I end up having here is big spikes on this power supply.

当这家伙的电源出现问题时，我也会看到其输出出现尖峰。好吧，那么解决方案是什么呢？这里有解决方案吗？我能做些什么来解决这个问题？什么？停止使用，正是如此。有疑问时，做点别的事。构建不同的设计。所以我能做的是，这很愚蠢，使用长线。

And when this guy’s power supply goes wacko, then I see the spikes on its output as well. OK, so what are the solutions for that? Any solutions here? What can I do to fix the problem? Pardon? Stop using the, exactly. When in doubt, do something else. Build a different design. So what I could do is this is pretty dumb, using a long wire.

所以，不，但相信我，很多时候你去储藏室，他们会给你一大卷电线，而你懒得剪下一段。使用整卷电线，使用两端，然后将其连接起来，好吗？所以，如果我有一段短得多的电线，那么这可以解决我的问题。但再次记住，对你来说很小的东西对电路来说可能并不小。

And so, no, but trust me, oftentimes you go to the store room and they give you a big roll of wire, and you’re too lazy to cut a piece out. Use the whole roll, and use the two ends, and connect it in, OK? So, if I had a much shorter piece of wire, then that can solve my problem. But again, remember, what’s small to you may not be small to the circuit.

好的，假设我是英特尔，我正在构建一个 10 GHz Pentium 6 处理器。好的，我的周期时间为 0.1 纳秒。在那里，即使是一根细小的电线也可能是一个真正的问题。好的，因此，在时钟频率为 10 GHz 的一英寸芯片上分配电力是一个非常非常困难的问题。

OK, so let’s say, for example, I’m Intel, and I’m building a 10 GHz Pentium 6 processor. OK, it’s 0.1 nanosecond is my cycle time. There, even a small, itty bitty wire can be a real problem. OK, and so therefore, distributing power throughout a one inch chip that’s clocking at 10 GHz is a really, really hard problem.

我们自己的 David Perreault 负责我们的一个部门，他是这个领域的世界专家之一。分配电源，就像我如何以稳定的方式将 1V 电压提供给芯片上的每个设备一样简单。这是一个难题。

And our own David Perreault, who is doing one of our sections, is one of the world’s experts in this field. Distributing power, something as simple as, how do I get 1V in a stable manner to every single device on my chip? It’s a hard problem.

好的，现在，您必须开始像 RC 电路一样为电源连接供电，并且您必须解决一些难题，才能在整个电路中合理地分配电力。那么，我还能做什么？是吗？再说一遍？啊，我可以做到。我可以使用不同的电线连接每个逆变器。这是一个很好的观点。

OK, so now, you have to begin feeding your power supply connections much like RC circuits, OK, and you have to solve some hard problems to be able to simply distribute power decently throughout your circuit. So, what else can I do? Yeah? Say it again? Ah, I can do that. I could use different wires to connect each of the inverters. That’s a good point.

耦合之所以发生，是因为我将两个反相器连接在这里。因此，我使用了不同的电缆。我之前没有想到这一点。这是一个有创意的解决方案。好吧，事实上，如果你制造一个芯片，那么我们在我们小组制造了这个称为 RAW 的芯片，它有大约 1000 万个门。

So here, the coupling happens because I connect the two inverters way out here. So instead, I use a different cable. I hadn’t thought of that. That’s a creative solution. OK, so in fact, if you build a chip, so we built this chip called RAW in our group, and it has on the order of 10 million gates.

我们用 IBM 的技术制造了这款芯片，事实证明，你不需要通过引脚送入电源，然后将 1.5V 电源连接到所有门。你需要做的是从该引脚构建特殊的电源缓冲树。每棵树，树的每片叶子都驱动一个子电路。换句话说，如果这是一个芯片，那么整个芯片中就有许多门。

And this chip we built with IBM’s technology, and it turns out that you don’t send power supply in through a pin and then connect that 1.5V supply to all your gates. What you do is from that pin, you then build special power supply buffering trees. And each tree, each leaf of the tree drives a subcircuit. In other words, if this is a chip, you have lots and lots of gates throughout your chip.

你不应该做的是引入这样的电源，然后连接。你不应该这样做。这是你能做的最糟糕的事情。由于刚才提到的原因，这绝对是一场灾难。好的，所以你应该做的是将芯片分成四个象限。好的，在我们的例子中，我们有 16 个象限。

What you do not do is bring in a power supply like this, and then connect. You don’t do that. That’s the worst possible thing you can do. It’s an absolute disaster for the reason just brought up. OK, so instead what you do is divide up the chip into, say, four quadrants. OK, in our case, we have 16 quadrants.

然后您要做的就是从这一点开始，取一根导线通向这个象限，一根导线通向这里，一根导线通向这里，一根导线通向这里，这样，电源就非常接近电源，并且您在每个象限都有不同的连接，这样，在这个象限切换时，不会因为这里导线的电感而影响到这个象限。

And then what you do is from this point, you take one wire that goes to this quadrant, one wire that comes here, one here, and one here, so that you’re getting the power supply very close to the source, and you have different connections going to each quadrant so that switching in this quadrant will not affect this guy because of the inductance of this lead here.

好的，如果你没有选修 6.002，你就会和 IBM 争论，我不要 16 根线。我只要一根线。好的，当然还有其他解决方案。还有几个解决方案。一个是，你可以做的是这里问题的一部分，即我的所有转换都非常非常尖锐。好的，所以 di/dt 非常非常大。

OK, and if you hadn’t taken 6.002, you’d have been arguing with IBM, I don’t want 16 wires. I want just one wire. OK, so there are other solutions, of course. There’s a couple more solution. One is that what you can do is part of the problem here is that all my transitions are really, really sharp. OK, so di/dt is very, very large.

因此，在数字和模拟电路设计中出现了一种全新的技术，也许我应该称之为波形工程，或者边缘工程。好吧，它也被称为边缘平滑。这个想法是，与其在电路中出现非常尖锐的边缘，不如尝试让边缘更平滑。当你有更平滑的边缘时，好吧，那么你的 di/dt 现在会更小。它不会非常非常高。

So, there’s a whole new technique in design of digital and analog circuits, which talks about, maybe I should call it waveform engineering, OK, or edge engineering. OK, it’s also called edge smoothing. The idea is that rather than have very sharp edges in your circuit, you try to have smoother edges. And when you have smoother edges, OK, then your di/dt is now going to be less. It’s not going to be very, very high.

相反，你的 delta I 会分散到更长的时间段内。当然，这意味着电路可能需要运行得慢一点，但这也可以解决问题。事实上，同样的波形平滑也是你在我们一个半月前看到的电容耦合中看到的解决方案。让我给你展示一下演示，然后关闭。不起作用？好的，没关系。没关系。

Rather, your delta I is spread out over a longer period of time. Of course, that means the circuits may have to run a little slower, but that can also solve the problem. And in fact, that same smoothing of the waveforms was also the solution you saw in the capacitive coupling we saw a month and a half ago. And let me show you the demo, and then close up. Not working? OK, that’s OK. It doesn’t matter.

所以如果你还记得一个半月前在电容器讲座上的演示，我谈到了一个有两个引脚的芯片，并且引脚之间存在电容耦合。因此，如果这个波形正在切换，那么由于这种耦合，你最终会得到，如果这是这里的信号，你最终会因为另一个引脚的信号而在这个引脚上得到尖峰。

So if you remember the demo from the lecture about a month and a half ago in capacitors, I talked about a chip with two pins, and there was this capacitive coupling between the pins. And because of this, if this waveform is switching, then because of this coupling, you will end up getting, if this is the signal here, you will end up getting spikes on this pin because of the signaling of the other pin.

这就是传统的电容耦合。好的，为了消除这种耦合，您可以做的与电感系统非常相似，如果您在这个引脚上没有急剧的过渡，而是有像这样的平滑过渡，那么您可以做的是，现在将 delta V 从这里扩展到这里的更长的 delta T。

And that’s good old capacitive coupling. OK, and to eliminate this, what you can do is much like with the inductance system, if you, rather than having sharp transitions on this pin, if you have smooth transitions that look like this, then what you can do is you’ll now spread delta V from here to here over a longer delta T.

好的，delta T 变得更长了，因此，你最终会得到更好的行为，并且不会出现这些尖峰。因此，如果你想构建非常非常快的电路，你必须非常小心。你可以构建快速电路，但要小心它们的快速边缘。好的，快速边缘很讨厌。它们会杀死你。这是你在构建下一代电路时要记住的事情。好吧，谢谢大家。我玩得很开心，希望你们也玩得很开心。谢谢。

OK, delta T has become longer, and because of that, you end up getting much better behavior, and you don’t end up getting these spikes. So therefore, if you want to build really, really fast circuits, you have to be really careful. You can build fast circuits, but watch out for them fast edges. OK, fast edges are nasty. They kill you. That’s something to remember as you build the next generation of circuits. Well, thank you all. I had a blast, and I hope you guys had fun too. Thank you.
